title: U.S. News: Biden Calls Trial Claims 'Hit Job' on Him
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
CLINTON, Iowa -- Before President Trump, no American president had ever sought re-election in the middle of an impeachment.
Former Vice President Joe Biden is contending with a similar distinction in the Democratic primaries, as a White House candidate caught up in the impeachment of Mr. Trump, whose trial centers on his pressing Ukraine to investigate Mr. Biden, a possible opponent in this year's election.
Days before the Iowa caucuses, Mr. Biden is trying to turn Republican efforts to damage him in the impeachment trial into a badge of honor and a sign of his resilience. His campaign hopes it will help him appeal to Democratic voters struggling to answer the contest's biggest question: Which Democrat is best positioned to defeat Mr. Trump in November's general election?
"This whole impeachment trial for Trump is just a political hit job to smear me," Mr. Biden told an audience Tuesday night in Clinton, a community along the Mississippi River. "That's how scared Trump is about having to run against me."
When Iowa Republican Sen. Joni Ernst suggested the Senate's trial in Washington could undercut Mr. Biden's appeal in Iowa, his campaign quickly seized upon her comments and posted a digital ad.
Mr. Trump's lawyers argued this week that the president was justified in seeking investigations into Mr. Biden and his son Hunter Biden, who served on the board of the Ukrainian natural-gas company Burisma while Mr. Biden was vice president. Mr. Biden has said he did nothing wrong in pressuring Ukraine to fire a prosecutor who had at one time been involved in investigating Burisma and who was widely viewed as insufficiently aggressive on corruption. Mr. Biden has also noted he was carrying out the Obama administration's Ukraine policy, which was in line with international partners on rooting out corruption.
Mr. Biden rarely hears questions from voters about the impeachment trial. But the uncertainty over how long it will last has loomed over the final week in Iowa.
Sens. Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren and Amy Klobuchar have been forced to scrap most of their Iowa campaign schedules to attend the trial.
The possibility of testimony at the impeachment trial from witnesses, such as former national security adviser John Bolton, could mean the proceeding spills over into campaigning ahead of the Feb. 11 New Hampshire primary.
It also could increase the likelihood that Mr. Biden's son, or even Mr. Biden himself, might be called to testify.
He told reporters this week that he had "nothing to defend. This is all a game."
Republicans, meanwhile, haven't been subtle about trying to use the trial to undermine Mr. Biden's candidacy.
Ms. Ernst, who is seeking re-election this year, told reporters that she was "really interested" to see how the arguments made by Mr. Trump's legal team "informs and influences the Iowa caucus voters."
Mr. Biden pounced, reading aloud the senator's comments during his events in Iowa. The campaign placed a homemade sign on the wall that said, "Joni -- We're w/ Joe."
"She spilled the beans," said Mr. Biden, who told his supporters, "You can ruin Donald Trump's night by caucusing for me, but also you can ruin Joni Ernst's night."
One of Ms. Ernst's Senate colleagues, meanwhile, bought airtime in Iowa to bolster Mr. Trump's defense. Sen. Rick Scott (R., Fla.) cut a 30-second ad accusing Mr. Biden of getting away with a pressure campaign against Ukraine and helping his son profit from his position, charges the Bidens and supporters have denied.
"I just see that as part of the desperation of the Republicans in facing him, that they've got to try to drag him and his son into this," said Jeff Hermiston, a retired teacher from West Liberty, Iowa, who saw Mr. Biden at a recent event and plans to caucus for him.

title: Trump Shares Tweet Naming Alleged Whistleblower; Whistleblower complaint set off congressional investigation that led to president's impeachment
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON—President Trump used his Twitter account to share a post naming the alleged whistleblower whose complaint set off the congressional investigation that led to his impeachment.
Late Friday night, Mr. Trump's Twitter account retweeted a tweet by a user named "Surfermom77" that identified the alleged whistleblower.
The Wall Street Journal and others have
previously reported
the whistleblower was a Central Intelligence Agency officer. Most mainstream news outlets haven't reported the whistleblower's name.
Democratic lawmakers and the whistleblower's attorneys have raised concerns that the person's safety could be put at risk if publicly identified, and they have pointed to laws that provide anonymity to intelligence employees who report wrongdoing. Mr. Trump and his allies have
questioned the whistleblower's motives
, challenging the person to step forward.
Several conservative news organizations have named a person they speculate is the whistleblower, and some Republican lawmakers have touted those articles on Twitter. The president's son, Donald Trump Jr., has also tweeted out the alleged whistleblower's name.
On Thursday, Mr. Trump retweeted a tweet from an account associated with the president's re-election campaign that linked to an article that names the alleged whistleblower.
The White House didn't immediately respond to a request for comment on the tweets. The whistleblower's lawyer didn't immediately respond to a message seeking comment.
In private conversations with allies in recent months, the president has mentioned reports in conservative media organizations that name the person alleged to be the whistleblower, according to people familiar with the conversations. This has prompted concerns among some in the administration that Mr. Trump could repeat the person's name publicly. Administration officials have cautioned the president against publicizing the name, according to people familiar with the matter.
The whistleblower filed an intelligence community complaint in August that raised concerns about Mr. Trump's July 25 call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, in which the president pressed for Kyiv to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden, a leading candidate in the 2020 Democratic presidential primary. The complaint was released publicly in September.
The Trump-appointed intelligence community inspector general, Michael Atkinson, determined the complaint was both urgent and credible. Mr. Trump has referred to the call as "perfect" and denied any wrongdoing in his interactions with Ukraine.
House Speaker Nancy Pelosi launched an impeachment investigation in September and the House voted along party lines to
impeach the president earlier this month
. The Senate is expected to convene a trial next year.
Twitter said Saturday that due to a system outage, tweets on some account profiles, including Mr. Trump's retweet on the alleged whistleblower, were visible to some but not others. The outage made it seem like the president's retweets had been deleted. But they reappeared in his Twitter feed later Saturday.
The issue affected millions of accounts, according to a spokesperson. "We're still working on fixing this and apologize for any confusion," Twitter said, adding that it was an internal system error, not a security issue.
Write to Andrew Restuccia at
Andrew.Restuccia@wsj.com

title: Trump's Loyal Base in Ohio Supports His Iran Strategy; President's re-election campaign seizes moment to portray him as a strong commander
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
COLUMBUS, Ohio—As President Trump
backs away from conflict with Iran
, some of his most loyal supporters say they never worried about the clash getting out of hand.
In the battleground state of Ohio, Trump backers attending a Wednesday campaign event with the president's daughter-in-law, Lara Trump, said they supported Mr. Trump's move to
take out an Iranian military leader
and that they didn't believe he was ever going to send ground troops into the country, based on his opposition to what he calls "endless wars."
"I come from a solid military family, so I know what it is to lose somebody," said Sherry Laughman, 57 years old, of Galena. "He has from the beginning said he was not in it to start a war."
Martha Verblaauw, also 57 and from Worthington, echoed that sentiment, saying: "I knew it wasn't going to happen. He literally follows through on things he's said from way back when."
SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS
How do you think President Trump's decision to strike against Iran will affect the presidential race? Join the conversation below.
As Mr. Trump appeared in Ohio on Thursday for his first major campaign rally since his confrontation with Iran intensified, his campaign seized the moment to portray him as a strong commander, touting the killing of an Iranian military leader and targeting what they see as mixed messages from Democrats. But the approach comes with risks, among them that should the conflict escalate, the president may turn off antiwar supporters.
"[Maj. Gen. Qassem] Soleimani was actively planning new attacks and he was looking very seriously at our embassies and not just at the embassy in Bagdhad," Mr. Trump said at the rally. "We stopped him quickly and we stopped him cold."
The threat of conflict with Iran intensified last week with the U.S.
strike against Gen. Soleimani
. The president sought to take down the temperature Wednesday, signaling no more military strikes after an
Iranian missile barrage on U.S. bases
, which was seen as a tempered response to the killing.
The president's re-election campaign has kept up its tough rhetoric.
Soon after the U.S. took out Gen. Soleimani, the Trump campaign sent out an email titled "ANOTHER dead terrorist," building on their tough talk after the
raid that killed an ISIS leader last year
. After the president's relatively measured address Wednesday, the campaign blasted a text to supporters, directing them to a survey that asked if they would prefer Mr. Trump in office or a "terrorist-apologist Democrat."
For their part, Democrats are casting Mr. Trump's effort as another example of a reckless policy. Speaking at a fundraiser Tuesday, former Vice President Joe Biden said: "We are alone now—we're alone and we will have to bear the cost of Donald Trump's folly."
Antiwar activists and lawmakers hosted a call Wednesday night with two Democratic presidential candidates where they discussed demonstrations set for Thursday in opposition to military action in the Middle East. Sens. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and Bernie Sanders of Vermont spoke briefly and urged listeners to be active in their resistance.
"This is the moment that Americans need to speak up and say we do not want another war in the Middle East, we do not want war with Iran," Ms. Warren said.
Mr. Trump's campaign has sought to highlight inconsistencies in Mr. Biden's foreign-policy record, as well as slam Mr. Sanders and Ms. Warren for their rhetoric about the strike against Gen. Soleimani.
"Now they are trying to defend killing a terrorist," Ms. Trump said Wednesday in Columbus. "What is going on with the Democrats?"
From the Oval Office Tuesday, Mr. Trump said: "I don't hear too many people other than politicians who are trying to win the presidency, those are the ones that are complaining, but I don't hear anybody else complaining."
Some Democratic voters in Ohio expressed frustration over Mr. Trump's tactics with Iran, although these voters said they had largely already made up their minds not to support him in 2020.
"It puts his foreignpolicy ineptitude on display," said Andy Steele, 46, of Columbus, who works for a technology company and plans to vote Democratic. Tom Hohenberger, a 64-year-old retired nurse from Columbus who also plans to vote Democratic, said, "I think he didn't get the right kind of briefing."
Rose Mary Blair, a 57-year-old project manager who attended an event in Akron for 2020 hopeful Michael Bloomberg Wednesday, said she thinks Mr. Trump's recent moves against Iran "put a lot of young people and our country at risk."
Mr. Trump's entanglement with Iran offers the latest example of a foreign policy that has long swung between aggressive and isolationist impulses. As a candidate, he pledged to stop "endless wars," but also promised to build up the U.S. military.
In office he has sought to withdraw troops from the Middle East while also promising to unleash "fire and fury" in the face of a nuclear threat.
Those close to the president said his views have always been complicated. Said one Trump ally: "Trump was never, never a noninterventionist in the way that Ron Paul was a noninterventionist."
Some Trump backers said they would be comfortable even if he did send troops into Iran, saying they trusted his judgment.
"If they want, I'll come out of retirement and I'll go over there" and help, said Curtis Stroede, 66, of Chillicothe, who is a veteran. "He's showing strength, he's pushing back on bullies, he's showing them he's willing and able."
Tarini Parti and Eliza Collins contributed to this article.
Write to Catherine Lucey at
catherine.lucey@wsj.com

title: Democrats Say Abuse of Power Warrants President's Removal
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON -- House Democrats argued before the Senate Thursday that President Trump should be convicted of an abuse-of-power charge, rebuffing the White House's position that the Constitution requires a criminal act to remove a president from office.
In the second day of arguments in the impeachment trial, the Democratic managers also laid out Thursday Mr. Trump's alleged motive for seeking investigations by Ukraine into former Vice President Joe Biden, a 2020 Democratic presidential candidate, saying Mr. Trump was determined to undercut a rival, not battle corruption, and that he put U.S. national security at risk as a result.
"A president who uses his office to ask for, or even worse, to compel foreign nations to meddle in our elections is a president who attacks the very foundation of our liberty," Rep. Jerrold Nadler (D., N.Y.), chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, said on the Senate floor. He said it is "without doubt a crime against the Constitution warranting, demanding, removal from office."
Mr. Trump and members of the president's defense team as well as many Republican lawmakers have dismissed the impeachment trial as a political assault by Democrats. They also argue that the "high crimes and misdemeanors" cited in the Constitution's impeachment clause require the allegation of a crime.
Speaking to reporters during a break in the proceedings, Jay Sekulow, an attorney for Mr. Trump, said the president's defense team will advance "multiple schools of thought" about what is an impeachable offense as they argue for his acquittal. "Our job here is to defend the president, the office of the presidency and the Constitution," he said.
One week after the senators were sworn in as trial jurors, Democrats remained hopeful of picking off some Republicans to support their calls for more documents and witnesses, such as hearing from former national security adviser John Bolton. Sen. Chuck Schumer of New York, the chamber's Democratic leader, said his party's presentations at the trial "may have planted the first seeds in their mind that, yes, perhaps the president did something very wrong here."
But several Republicans said the presentation wasn't telling them anything new. "There was certainly a lot of repetition," said Sen. Lisa Murkowski (R., Alaska), who previously said she was open to supporting votes for new evidence.
Democrats need 51 votes in the GOP-controlled Senate to call witnesses, while a two-thirds supermajority would be required to remove Mr. Trump from office.
Under the rules governing the third presidential impeachment trial in U.S. history, the House managers and Mr. Trump's defense team each have 24 hours spread over three days to make their arguments. The House team used about eight hours of its time Wednesday and used about eight more Thursday.
Democrats are expected to turn to the second article of impeachment, focused on Mr. Trump's alleged efforts to block documents and testimony sought by House investigators, on Friday.
During his presentation, Mr. Nadler outlined the legal underpinnings of abuse of power, arguing that it has been at the center of previous presidential impeachments.
"The charges set forth in the first article of impeachment are firmly grounded in the Constitution of the United States," he said.
The managers played a series of clips, including decades-old videos of Sen. Lindsey Graham (R., S.C.) and Harvard Law Prof. Alan Dershowitz, now a member of Mr. Trump's defense team, in which each argued that certain acts deserve impeachment even if they aren't illegal under criminal statutes.
Mr. Dershowitz, in a CNN interview Sunday, said he would argue that even if House Democrats' allegations about the president are true, they don't rise to the level of an impeachable offense because they aren't crimes.
The impeachment managers have argued that Mr. Trump withheld nearly $400 million in military aid to Ukraine as part of an effort to pressure Kyiv to open investigations into Mr. Biden. The Trump administration released the aid in September after protests from lawmakers in both parties.
Much of Thursday's arguments focused on Mr. Trump's request, during a July 25 phone call with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, that Ukraine probe Mr. Biden. Mr. Trump also mentioned the subject of aid during the call, but didn't tie the two together.
Mr. Biden helped lead an international anticorruption push in Ukraine while vice president. His son Hunter Biden served on the board of a Ukranian natural-gas company at the time. Mr. Trump and his allies have accused Mr. Biden of working to replace a Ukrainian prosecutor to protect his son, but Mr. Biden pressed for the removal with the backing of U.S. allies at a time when the prosecutor's probe into Burisma, the gas company, was dormant.
The Bidens have strenuously denied any wrongdoing.
In his closing remarks, lead impeachment manager Rep. Adam Schiff said Mr. Trump posed a danger to the country unless removed from office.
"You can't trust this president to do what's right for this country," the California Democrat said. "You can trust he will do what's right for Donald Trump. He'll do it now, he's done it before, he'll do it for the next several months. He'll do it in the election if he's allowed to."
---
Rebecca Ballhaus and Natalie Andrews contributed to this article.

title: Sanders Campaign Looks to Move On From Caucus Chaos; Vermont senator declared victory in Iowa while results were still coming in, announced big January fundraising
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit





Volunteers and supporters of Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders at a watch party during the Iowa caucuses on Monday. Mr. Sanders's presidential campaign is now pivoting to New Hampshire. PHOTO: Christopher Lee for The Wall Street Journal
When the going gets tough, Bernie Sanders's aides talk about what happened on Oct. 4.
That was the day the Vermont senator left the hospital after a heart attack, just after the lowest point in his presidential bid, and a reminder that the campaign has proven it can turn things around.
This week, after chaotic results out of the Iowa Democratic Party and no clear answer about who won the state's presidential caucuses, aides acknowledged frustration. So the campaign sought to reset ahead of next week's New Hampshire primary, declaring victory in Iowa while results were still coming in and disclosing massive January fundraising.
Mr. Sanders had a lead in the popular vote with 97% of precincts reporting as of Thursday. But he and former South Bend Indiana Mayor Pete Buttigieg were locked in a tight race for the metric that Iowa Democrats consider most important, so-called state delegate equivalents. On Thursday, the chair of the Democratic Party called for a recanvass—the auditing of paper records from each precinct's caucus—after technical problems marred the tabulation of results.
"Where I come from and where everybody else comes from, the person who gets the most votes wins," Mr. Sanders said during a press conference in Manchester, N.H. "We got the most votes."
In interviews, Mr. Sanders's top aides said they plan to stick with their strategy of appealing to young people and minorities, saying the candidate did well in Iowa precincts with large populations of those groups. On Thursday,
the campaign announced it received $25 million from grass-roots donors in January
—more than many candidates raised in entire quarters last year—and said it is investing $5.5 million in advertising in 10 states set to vote in late February and early March.
Mr. Sanders has been leading in polls in New Hampshire, too.
"I am confident that here in New Hampshire, I know you'll be able to count your votes on election night," Mr. Sanders told a crowd in Milford, N.H., Tuesday night. "And when you count those votes, I look forward to winning here in New Hampshire."
The Iowa results carried some warning signs for Mr. Sanders.
The close race with Mr. Buttigieg
, a 38-year-old Washington outsider who has sought to appeal to moderates, reveals the Democratic Party remains ideologically divided and is still deciding what type of candidate should take on President Trump.
Some more centrist voters worry that Mr. Sanders—a self-described Democratic socialist—could scare off moderate Republicans and independent voters looking for an alternative to President Trump. And Mr. Sanders could face difficulty expanding his base if the field narrows. His strategy to rack up delegates relies on a fractured Democrats field. If candidates were to drop out, early voters could coalesce around one of his opponents.
The caucuses also saw lower-than-expected turnout, despite the Vermont senator's vow to expand the electorate.
Mr. Sanders narrowly lost the state in his long-shot bid for the Democratic nomination in 2016. This time, Mr. Sanders announced his run in February with strong name identification and a more experienced team.
To move ahead of a crowded field, the Sanders campaign invested in its ground game in Iowa. On Feb. 1, the campaign announced it had knocked on half a million doors since the beginning of January. As of Monday, the Sanders campaign had bought nearly $11 million worth of TV and radio advertisements in the state, trailing just businessman Tom Steyer, who spent over $16 million.
Jane O'Meara Sanders, Mr. Sanders's wife, also said campaigning in the final days before the caucuses felt different than it did four years ago.
"I felt that in 2016, we were introducing him at every venue, we were introducing Bernie Sanders to Iowa," Mrs. Sanders said in an interview the weekend before the Iowa caucuses. 





Mr. Sanders's supporters in Iowa PHOTO: Christopher Lee for The Wall Street Journal
While nine out of 10 people in Iowa are white, the Sanders campaign also
focused on increasing turnout from voters in minority communities
and sent organizers to talk with people in areas with large Latino populations, said Misty Rebik, his Iowa state director. Mr. Sanders also held an event on a Native American settlement in Iowa and focused on how his policies would affect those in attendance. Mr. Sanders and the rest of the field have struggled for the support of African-American voters, particularly older ones, who have flocked to former Vice President Joe Biden.
Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez met with Latinos on her trips to the state. Her decision to endorse the Vermont senator while he was still in the hospital last fall helped give a shot of energy to a lagging campaign, as did those of two other liberal congresswomen, Rep. Ilhan Omar (D., Minn.) and Rep. Rashida Tlaib (D., Mich.).
All three were in Iowa for Mr. Sanders in the last two weeks, campaigning across the state as he was stuck in Washington for the impeachment trial of President Trump.
Aides believe Mr. Sanders was able to consolidate support in the final weeks after voters looked at other candidates and compared them to Mr. Sanders, who has been calling for the same policies for decades.
Heather Purdy, a 45-year-old professor from Des Moines, said she had decided on Mr. Sanders the week before the caucuses. Ms. Purdy had been considering Mr. Sanders and Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren, but she said the Vermont lawmaker's consistency ultimately won her over.
"He's had the same platform for the last 40 years," she said.
Chad Day and Joshua Jamerson contributed to this article.
Write to Eliza Collins at
eliza.collins@wsj.com.

title: After Democrats' Caucus Woes, Trump Praises Iowa, New Hampshire; Both of the early-nominating states could be in play in the November election
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
As Democrats seek to move past
Iowa's caucus chaos
, President Trump is praising the state—along with the fellow early-voting New Hampshire—as he calls for them to remain atop the primary calendar.
Mr. Trump tweeted Friday: "Iowa and New Hampshire will not be moved from the Primary Schedule as long as I am President. Great tradition!"
His comments came as some national Democrats
have been calling for the end
of Iowa's early-voting tradition after the results debacle that followed Monday's caucuses. Iowa and New Hampshire, which has its primary on Tuesday, have long faced criticism for their outsize role in the nomination process, given that they are smaller, mostly white, states.
The president doesn't play a direct role in determining the nomination calendar. Each state decides when to hold its primary or caucus, though the Democratic National Committee and Republican National Committee can influence those decisions by how they allocate delegates to the states.
Both of the first two states are key general election battlegrounds. Mr. Trump captured Iowa by nearly 10 percentage points in 2016 over Hillary Clinton, but former President Obama won there in 2008 and 2012. Mr. Trump narrowly lost New Hampshire in 2016 and sees it as a pickup opportunity in the fall.
Mr. Trump also hasn't held back on criticizing Iowa's Democratic caucuses, which were riddled with technical glitches and other issues, leading the Iowa Democratic Party to take days to release the results. Democratic National Committee Chairman Tom Perez has called for
a recanvass of the results
, and the Associated Press reported it was unable to declare a winner.
At an event later in the day Friday, Mr. Trump criticized the process in Iowa, saying, "It's sad. It's embarrassing."
Leading Democrats have expressed concerns about Iowa's future in the wake of the caucuses. Senate Minority Whip Dick Durbin (D., Ill.) said on MSNBC this week: "The Democratic caucus is a quirky, quaint tradition that should come to an end."
Iowa and New Hampshire are both fiercely protective of their early-voting status, which confers both political prestige and economic benefits.
Top Republicans from Iowa issued a statement this week calling for the tradition to continue. "Iowa's bipartisan first-in-the-nation status helped lead to the nomination of President Obama and has the full backing of President Trump," said the statement signed by Iowa Gov. Kim Reynolds, Sen. Joni Ernst and Sen. Chuck Grassley. "The process is not suffering because of a short delay in knowing the final results."
Write to Catherine Lucey at
catherine.lucey@wsj.com

title: Trump Campaign Talks Up Trade Deals as 'Promises Kept,' but Uncertainty Over China Lingers; Any political momentum could fade if Beijing fails to follow through on commitments to increase U.S. imports
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON—President Trump is seizing on
the trade deal with China
as proof that he is delivering on his campaign promises, but whether that message resonates with voters could hinge on how the agreement plays out in the coming months.
For now, Mr. Trump and his campaign say the deal with China—along with Thursday's Senate passage of
a reworked North American trade pact
—has shown that the president can stake out tough positions to achieve better deals for American businesses and workers and will do so again to win additional concessions.
The campaign is planning ads around the trade deals that seek to reinforce a broad "promises made, promises kept" message and target American workers, including union members and factory workers whose industries have been hit by decades of U.S. trade policy. Mr. Trump is expected to give greater prominence to the deals in coming rallies, according to a person familiar with the planning. On Sunday, he highlighted the pacts before the American Farm Bureau Federation's annual convention in Austin, Texas.
The China deal, while limited in scope, calmed a tumultuous two-year trade war under Mr. Trump and could help maintain a strong economy that has been his strongest asset heading into his re-election bid.
SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS
How confident are you in President Trump's trade strategy? Join the conversation below.
"He's sort of settled things down," said Republican pollster Dave Winston, who isn't associated with Mr. Trump's campaign. "You've seen the stock market respond positively, and that's a lot of people's retirement. This is a reinforcement, at least for the moment, that the economy is headed in a positive direction."
Mr. Trump's campaign and Republican allies are also seeking to contrast the trade deals this week with
the president's impeachment and trial
getting under way in the Senate on charges of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress. They contend that his efforts signal to voters that he is getting things done despite the partisan battles in Washington.
"Every candidate for president over many decades has promised to stand up to China, but no one ever did until Donald Trump came along. The signing of the phase-one deal shows that his America First approach is working," said campaign spokesman Tim Murtaugh.
But any political momentum over Mr. Trump's handling of China could fade
if Beijing fails to follow through on its commitments
to increase its U.S. imports by $200 billion over two years. Tougher trade issues also remain unresolved and have been punted to future negotiations—and, notably, painful tariffs remain in place. While the economy is strong, U.S. factory output has slowed.
"True to form, Trump is getting precious little in return for the significant pain and uncertainty he has imposed on our economy, farmers and workers," said former Vice President Joe Biden, a leading candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination.
Other Democratic candidates have also criticized Mr. Trump over what they describe as erratic negotiation tactics, but they have generally supported a tougher stance on China. And
the new trade deal with Mexico and Canada
was shaped by Democrats and drew mostly praise.
As a candidate in 2016, Mr. Trump made American jobs a central focus of his campaign and repeatedly said China was ripping off the U.S. and blasted large trade deals such as NAFTA and the proposed Trans-Pacific Partnership. That message helped Mr. Trump narrowly flip industrial states Michigan, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin.
"It was hugely effective," said Democratic pollster Stanley Greenberg.
But tariffs that Mr. Trump imposed on hundreds of billions of dollars in Chinese imports drew backlash from the business community and rattled farmers, who saw retaliatory action from Beijing and plummeting sales that required billions in government payments.
The phase-one deal reached this week leaves in place U.S. tariffs on about $370 billion in Chinese goods. Mr. Greenberg said public opinion polls show the tariffs are unpopular, particularly among independent voters, and that will impede Mr. Trump's efforts to portray the deal as a win.
Alex Conant, a Republican strategist in Washington who advises some companies fighting Mr. Trump's trade policies, agreed on that point. "The most important factor in Trump's re-election is the economy, and tariffs are bad for American consumers and businesses."
Mr. Trump on Thursday said the China deal was evidence that his tariff strategy had paid off, tweeting that "farmers are really happy" with the outcome.
As Democratic presidential candidates gathered last Tuesday for the debate in Des Moines, Iowa, Mr. Trump's campaign paid for a plane to fly over the city, towing a green banner that read "Trump Fights for Iowa Farmers!"
On the debate stage, Democrats echoed themes Mr. Trump harnessed in 2016, but still sought ways to criticize his approach to trade negotiations. Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont noted his past votes against Nafta and extending permanent normal trade relations with China. "The answer," he added, "is we could do much better than a Trump-led trade deal."
Write to Alex Leary at
alex.leary@wsj.com

title: Democrats Present Case for Trump's Removal
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON -- House Democrats argued that President Trump's efforts to press Ukraine to launch investigations that could help him politically warranted his removal from office, saying during the first day of opening arguments in the Senate impeachment trial that his actions undercut U.S. elections and national security.
Rep. Adam Schiff, the lead impeachment manager and chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, laid out the allegations underpinning the two articles of impeachment passed by the House last month. The first stems from Mr. Trump pressing Ukraine to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden, a 2020 Democratic presidential candidate. The second accuses Mr. Trump of impeding Congress's investigation by blocking some witnesses and documents.
"Over the coming days, you will hear remarkably consistent evidence of President Trump's corrupt scheme and coverup," Mr. Schiff (D., Calif.) said, standing at a lectern on the Senate floor. "There is no serious dispute about the facts underlying the president's conduct."
Mr. Trump, a Republican, maintains he did nothing wrong and has called the impeachment a hoax driven by politics.
The Democrats, in laying out their case, continued to try to persuade Republicans to support calling new witnesses and documents, which Democrats argue will provide more details about Mr. Trump's interactions with top aides, including former national security adviser John Bolton and acting chief of staff Mick Mulvaney.
Mr. Trump's legal team argues that Democrats don't have a strong case, saying that weakness is why the prosecutors seek more witnesses. They will be able to counter after the Democratic team finishes its three days of arguments.
Trump lawyer Jay Sekulow said that the team plans to "challenge aggressively" Democrats' case. "There's a lot of things I'd like to rebut and we will rebut," he said.
Speaking at a news conference at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, Mr. Trump said he was sympathetic toward the idea of a longer Senate trial with witness testimony, but didn't budge on his position regarding several witnesses sought by Democrats.
"I would rather go the long way. I would rather interview Bolton. I would rather interview a lot of people," he said. But he added that testimony from Mr. Bolton, as well as that of Mr. Mulvaney, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and former Energy Secretary Rick Perry, would pose national security concerns.
The White House had instructed many witnesses, including Mr. Bolton, not to testify in the House probe. Any new witnesses would have to be deposed privately before they could testify before the Senate.
As part of his presentation, Mr. Schiff played a clip of Mr. Mulvaney from October in which Mr. Mulvaney said, "Get over it. There is going to be political influence in foreign policy." Mr. Mulvaney made the comment while answering reporters' questions related to the administration's freeze on aid to Ukraine. Democrats have said the freeze was part of a quid pro quo for Ukraine launching investigations into Mr. Biden.
"Should we just get over it?" Mr. Schiff asked the senators. "Is that what we've come to? I hope and pray that the answer is no."
Mr. Schiff argued that the senators needed to take action now, or they risk setting a precedent that could undermine future elections and U.S. global standing while bolstering autocrats such as President Vladimir Putin of Russia.
"What message will we send if we choose not to hold this president accountable for his abuse of power, to solicit re-election interference in our upcoming election?" He added: "We have for generations been the shining city upon a hill that President Reagan described. . .but what worth is that idea if when tried we do not affirm the values that underpin it?"
House managers laid out the chronology of the Democrats' case, playing video clips of administration officials who testified in the House investigation about the president's push for investigations and the hold on nearly $400 million in military aid to Ukraine. The aid later was released after bipartisan pressure in Congress.
Just before 2 a.m. Wednesday, the Senate passed a resolution in a 53-47 vote along party lines setting the structure for the trial, which doesn't include guarantees for new witnesses or documents.
Democrats still hope to win over at least four votes to seek subpoenas later in the trial. Some GOP lawmakers have said they are open to new witnesses, but they want to wait until after the Democrats and Mr. Trump's legal team have made their cases.
Headed into their opening arguments, Republicans said they were taken aback by comments from House Judiciary Chairman Jerrold Nadler (D., N.Y.), who, while arguing for a Democratic amendment to the trial rules, said in the early hours Wednesday that senators who voted against allowing witnesses were "complicit in the president's coverup."
"I was offended; I took it as very offensive as one who is listening attentively and working hard to get to a fair process," said Sen. Lisa Murkowski (R., Alaska,), whose support Democrats likely will need to call new evidence.
Some Republicans have pushed the idea that for every possible witness that Democrats want to call, the GOP would call in a witness of their own. That could include Mr. Biden or his son Hunter, whom Republicans have criticized for serving on the board of a Ukrainian natural gas company while his father was the Obama administration's point man for combating Ukrainian corruption. The Bidens have denied any wrongdoing.
The former vice president said he opposed the idea of testifying in order to call Republicans' bluff and potentially get a witness that Democrats want, adding that he doesn't want the process to "turn into a farce."
---
Tarini Parti contributed to this article.

title: The Bloomberg Effect: Huge Spending Transforms 2020 Campaign Dynamics; Michael Bloomberg has spent roughly three-quarters of the amount spent by all other presidential campaigns combined on ads
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
The presidential election is 10 months away,
but Michael Bloomberg's long-shot campaign
is running like it's already late October.
The candidate has spent $217 million so far on television and digital advertising, mostly ignoring the Democratic primaries and squarely challenging President Trump. The total is roughly three-quarters of the amount spent by all other campaigns, including Mr. Trump's, combined.
It's the game plan the billionaire used in his campaign for mayor of New York City in 2001, when he outspent his competitor nearly 5 to 1. Big spending has also made his philanthropy
a dominant force on climate change, gun control and other issues
. And it is how he has managed his lucrative business, paying up to bring in talent.
The flow of cash—dubbed the Bloomberg effect by media-measurement firm Advertising Analytics LLC—has upended the financial dynamics of the election. Television ad rates jumped 45% in Houston after the Bloomberg campaign bought $1 million worth of ads in November, Advertising Analytics said. The
campaign paid as much as double the going rate for staff and promised jobs to workers through November
, whether or not Mr. Bloomberg stays in the race. The candidate, who is funding his run entirely by himself, now has 1,000 campaign staffers.
It's a big part of the reason roughly $20 billion is expected to be spent on political advertising this election cycle, dwarfing the previous record of $12 billion in 2016, according to media research firm, Borrell Associates.
"Everything about what Bloomberg is doing is unprecedented," said Rufus Gifford, former finance director for Barack Obama's presidential campaign. Mr. Bloomberg remains a long shot, Mr. Gifford said, "but when you have Donald Trump as president and one of the 10 richest people running for president, anything can happen."
Kevin Sheekey, Mr. Bloomberg's campaign manager, said there's more to
Mr. Bloomberg's candidacy
than his spending, pointing to wealthy but politically inexperienced candidates such as Meg Whitman or Ross Perot who failed in the past. "Money won't just determine elections," he said. "You have to have a record and a message."
Lots of rich people have run for office, lots of candidates have claimed excellent business credentials and many have claimed to have top-flight data operations, which Mr. Bloomberg emphasizes. What sets his campaign apart is his $55 billion checkbook.
Mr. Bloomberg is No. 9 on the Forbes list of the world's richest people, ahead of each of the Google founders, either Koch brother and the wealthiest members of the Walton family. A person familiar with the plans said he could spend $500 million on the primaries alone, and Mr. Bloomberg hasn't ruled out spending $1 billion before November if needed.
"Certainly it's going to be disruptive," said Robert Wolf, former chairman and CEO of UBS Americas and a longtime Democratic donor. "We just don't know how yet."
Mr. Bloomberg, who was mayor of New York from 2002 to 2013, is currently supported by 6% of voters, compared with 27% for former Vice President Joe Biden in the Real Clear Politics average of polls. More voters have a negative than a positive view of Mr. Bloomberg, according to a Quinnipiac University National Poll from mid-December.
Mr. Bloomberg said he entered the race at a moment when polling data suggested voters placed less importance on ideology and more on finding a candidate who could beat Mr. Trump. His campaign believed Mr. Trump was winning the race and was going unchallenged in political ads in competitive states as Democratic candidates focused on the primary battle.
At the time, Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren was surging. Polls showed Mr. Biden beating Mr. Trump but within the margin of error. Ms. Warren's policies, such as a wealth tax, would likely hurt Mr. Bloomberg, and she is generally disliked by his circle of wealthy New Yorkers, according to a longtime staff member. Mr. Bloomberg has said he will back whoever wins the nomination, even if it is Ms. Warren or Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders.
To offset criticism that he was running out of his own self interest, Mr. Bloomberg pledged $15 million to $20 million to register 500,000 voters before the election. His attacks on Mr. Trump are part of that effort.
"There's a sense that Bloomberg is doing something that the party can't do—going negative on Trump," Mr. Gifford said. "It's work that the party doesn't have the money to do, and other candidates don't have the ability to do."
After Mr.
Trump's campaign said it had bought a 60-second TV spot during the Super Bowl on Feb. 2
, the Bloomberg campaign bought a 60-second spot that will target the president. The Bloomberg campaign declined to disclose how much it was spending for the spot, but advertising tracker Kantar/CMAG estimates it is worth $10 million.
Bloomberg spending has drawn Mr. Trump's attention. When the campaign aired an ad saying the president had broken his promise of protecting those with pre-existing health conditions, Mr. Trump pushed back on Twitter and labeled Mr. Bloomberg "Mini Mike."
Mr. Bloomberg's campaign said that because he started late, it is focusing on the Super Tuesday votes on March 3, rather than the early voting states such as Iowa and New Hampshire. The plan plays to Mr. Bloomberg's financial advantage and minimizes his weaknesses—shaking hands and making small talk with voters, and giving stump speeches. The
Super Tuesday states
, where 40% of delegates will be chosen, instead depend more on television and digital advertising.
In addition to huge TV spending—$193 million on ads since his campaign began—the campaign has spent heavily online. It spent $16.1 million on Google ads as of Jan. 11 and $6.8 million on Facebook as of the end of December according to Kantar/CMAG.
Mr. Trump has spent $6.5 million on digital ads, and Tom Steyer, the other billionaire Democratic candidate, has spent $5.6 million since Mr. Bloomberg entered the race in November, as of the end of last year.
The Bloomberg campaign is offering field organizers salaries of $6,000 a month. For state data directors, it's between $10,000 and $12,000 a month, according to job postings.
The campaign's 1,000-person payroll is more typical of an operation in the final months before Election Day. Mr. Biden has roughly 400 campaign staffers, while Mr. Sanders has built an 800-person staff.
The former mayor's late entry into the race has forced the campaign to "create a sense of momentum and hope people will actually jump on," said a person familiar with Mr. Bloomberg's state operations.
Campaign veterans said money won't necessarily bring in the best staff and said many experienced staffers want to work for people they support. Other campaigns, including Ms. Warren's and Mr. Sanders's, already have operations in Super Tuesday states and are ramping up hiring in later states.
Mr. Bloomberg has spent in markets that haven't been targeted by other Democrats. His campaign has plunked down $21.2 million on television advertising in Texas, where none of the leading Democrats have spent a penny. It has spent $8.4 million in Pennsylvania, which doesn't hold its primary until April 28.
It has even poured resources into smaller states that are typically not on the primary radar. In Idaho, it has spent $979,000 so far; in Utah, $1.6 million.
"He is going far, far ahead of where the rest of the guys are scrumming," said Kip Cassino, executive vice president at Borrell Associates, the media research firm. "He is basically saying, 'I'm not going to win in Iowa, and I am not going to get out there and kiss pigs. And I won't win in New Hampshire, but I will win in the rest of the states, and I will get the states that most everyone didn't care about before.' "
At the beginning of January, candidates had spent close to $540 million on political ads in the presidential race over the prior 12 months, about 10 times what would have been expected at this point in this election cycle, Mr. Cassino said.
"We have never seen anything like this," Mr. Cassino said, referring to Mr. Bloomberg's spending. "We are only just starting to see how distorting this might be."
Mr. Bloomberg's potential handicaps among Democratic voters include his support for Republican candidates in the past, including former President George W. Bush. Other issues that could hurt are his support for charter schools in his education-reform efforts, and the stop-and-frisk policy he adopted as mayor, in which New York police had wide latitude to detain and search passersby for contraband. A federal judge eventually ruled the policy violated the constitutional rights of minorities. Mr. Bloomberg apologized for the stop-and-frisk policy before he kicked off his campaign.
Share Your Thoughts
What are Michael Bloomberg's chances at the Democratic nomination, as of today? Why? Join the discussion below.
Some Democrats fear Mr. Bloomberg could drag out the primary with his limitless budget, or use his money to try to influence the leading candidates, hoping to pull some of them to the political center, which he sees as the way to beat Mr. Trump.
Mr. Bloomberg's team said the data operation he is building will benefit Democrats overall, which he said are far behind the Republicans on the gathering and use of voter data. His data firm, Hawkfish LLC, launched in the spring. It has hired Facebook's former chief marketing officer and the former CEO of Foursquare, the location tracking firm.
Mr. Bloomberg has cited his research and spending on the 2018 midterm elections as evidence of his commitment to the party's success. Democratic candidates won 21 of the 24 races in which he was involved. In most races, the spending focused on digital advertising early in the election cycle and TV advertising closer to election day, when ad reservations were more expensive and Republican groups could not as easily counter their message.
In an Oklahoma House of Representatives race, which appeared to be a long-shot for the Democrats, Mr. Bloomberg unleashed a wave of last-minute ads that attacked the Republican candidate. Democrat Kendra Horn won by a few thousand votes.
"I supported 24 candidates who were good on guns and good on environment, and 21 of them won, and that flipped the House," he said at a recent campaign stop in Philadelphia. "So if it wasn't for that, you wouldn't have [Speaker of the House Nancy] Pelosi and you wouldn't have impeachment."
Gregory Zuckerman contributed to this article.
Write to Tarini Parti at
Tarini.Parti@wsj.com
and Lukas I. Alpert at
lukas.alpert@wsj.com

title: Key Swing Senator, Lamar Alexander, to Vote Against New Witnesses in Impeachment Trial; Another GOP swing vote, Sen. Susan Collins, said she would vote in favor of hearing new testimony
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON—A Republican senator who party leaders feared might join Democrats in seeking new testimony said Thursday night he will vote against calling witnesses, bolstering the GOP's chances of bringing the
impeachment trial of President Trump
to a rapid conclusion.
Sen. Lamar Alexander (R., Tenn.) announced his plan after senators wrapped their second and
final day of questioning
Mr. Trump's legal team and House Democratic impeachment managers, during which the two sides sparred over the
limits of executive and congressional power
while revealing little new information.
Mr. Alexander said he believed that Democrats proved their core allegation that Mr.
Trump withheld aid from Ukraine
to pressure Kyiv to launch investigations into former Vice President Joe Biden and his son. But he said those actions, while inappropriate, didn't merit the president's removal from office, and therefore no witnesses were needed.
"There is no need for more evidence to prove something that has already been proven and that does not meet the U.S. Constitution's high bar for an impeachable offense," Mr.
Alexander tweeted
.
Mr. Alexander had notified Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R., Ky.) of his decision before announcing it. Mr. McConnell, leaving the Capitol on Thursday, said only: "Tomorrow's a big day."
Another GOP swing vote, Sen. Susan Collins of Maine, said she would vote in favor of hearing new testimony, saying that hearing from witnesses would allow each side "to more fully and fairly make their case, resolve any ambiguities and provide additional clarity." But Democrats need four Republicans to join them for the vote to be successful.
While Mr. Alexander's decision doesn't mean Republicans are certain to have enough votes to block new testimony, it suggests the GOP is in a good position ahead of Friday's vote, which is likely to pave the way for Mr. Trump's swift acquittal. Mr. Alexander, who was spotted reading Jon Meacham's "Impeachment: An American History" in the Senate chamber earlier Thursday, had remained silent over the course of the week about how he might vote.
In addition to Ms. Collins, Sen. Mitt Romney (R., Utah) has said he is interested in hearing from witnesses. And Sen. Lisa Murkowski (R., Alaska) said late Thursday she is still on the fence.
On Tuesday, Mr. McConnell told Republicans they didn't yet have the
votes to block the measure
. In the days since, Republicans have expressed more confidence.
At Thursday's GOP lunch, Mr. McConnell didn't disclose where the vote count on witnesses stood, and Republican leaders said they didn't yet know what Friday would bring. "It's going to be very, very close," Sen. Mike Braun (R., Ind.) said.
Some Republican senators are suggesting that if they succeed in blocking witnesses on Friday, they will push to end the trial that night, even if that means a vote to acquit Mr. Trump could occur in the wee hours of the morning on Saturday.
Meanwhile, preparing for the possibility of a defeat on the witness vote, Democrats are exploring parliamentary maneuvers that they could use to fight such an abrupt end to the trial and draw attention to what they consider an unfair process.
SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS
What are your biggest takeaways from the impeachment Q&A? Why? Join the conversation below.
House Democrats over two days of questioning focused on the need for the chamber to call new witnesses—in particular, Mr. Trump's former national security adviser John Bolton. On Sunday,
a draft was leaked of Mr. Bolton's forthcoming book
, in which he wrote that Mr. Trump told him he was freezing security aid to Ukraine until it opened investigations into Mr. Joe Biden, a leading Democratic presidential candidate, and other matters.
Mr. Bolton has said
he would testify if subpoenaed
by the Senate. The Republican president has denied Mr. Bolton's account and has called the impeachment case against him a hoax.
Ms. Murkowski, in a question posed to the president's legal team, said the dispute over Mr. Bolton's book "weighs in favor of calling additional witnesses" and asked why the Senate shouldn't call Mr. Bolton, suggesting she was leaning toward voting for new testimony.
But later, she and Mr. Alexander signed on to a question asking, Even if the reports of the contents of Mr. Bolton's book were accurate, "isn't it true that the allegations would still not rise to an impeachable offense?" The Trump defense team agreed.
Democrats argued witnesses were central to the trial process.
"God forbid we should hear what a relevant witness has to say," said Rep. Adam Schiff (D., Calif.), the lead House manager and chairman of the chamber's Intelligence Committee. He proposed limiting witness testimony to one week, responding to concerns from Republicans and some Democrats about prolonging the trial with new testimony and the court battles that could ensue from any new subpoenas. The presidential nomination contests begin on Monday in Iowa.
Democrats have argued that Mr. Trump was trying to cheat in this year's election. Mr. Trump's lawyers tried to turn the tables on Democrats, accusing them of using impeachment to interfere in this year's vote. "That is the most massive election interference in our history," said White House counsel Pat Cipollone, echoing a tweet by Mr. Trump days earlier. "Let's leave it to the people of the United States."
Sen. Chuck Schumer of New York, the Democratic leader, on Thursday played down the possibility that Chief Justice John Roberts, who is presiding over the trial, could step in to break a 50-50 tie over calling witnesses. Mr. Schumer said Democrats remain focused on getting to 51 votes. It isn't clear how Mr. Roberts would handle a 50-50 tally, and the Senate rules are silent on the matter.
Thursday's session began on a dramatic note as the chief justice declined to read a question submitted by Sen. Rand Paul (R., Ky.) that included the name of a person identified by some people as the anonymous whistleblower who helped set off the impeachment inquiry. The whistleblower's lawyer hasn't confirmed the person's name.
Mr. Trump's lawyers used Thursday to try to challenge basic elements of Democrats' impeachment case. Deputy White House counsel Pat Philbin argued that on a July 25 call with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, Mr. Trump wasn't asking "specifically for an investigation" into Mr. Biden and his son Hunter. A rough transcript of the call released by the White House shows that Mr. Trump asked his Ukrainian counterpart to look into the Bidens, saying "whatever you can do with the Attorney General would be great."
Mr. Trump and his allies have alleged that it was corrupt for the elder Mr. Biden during the Obama administration to seek the ouster of a Ukrainian prosecutor who had once investigated a Ukrainian gas company where his son sat on the board. Mr. Biden sought the prosecutor's removal as part of a broad international effort to combat corruption in Ukraine. The Bidens have denied any wrongdoing, though Hunter Biden has said it was poor judgment to serve on the Burisma board, which paid him $50,000 a month, while his father was involved with Ukraine policy as vice president.
Mr. Philbin also argued that "the evidence just doesn't stack up" to show Mr. Trump linked aid or a White House meeting to Ukraine opening investigations. But he didn't address the possibility of testimony by Mr. Bolton, who, based on his leaked manuscript, could offer such evidence.
Thursday's session also renewed focus on the activities in Ukraine of Rudy Giuliani, Mr. Trump's personal lawyer. In response to a question from a bipartisan group of senators—including two Republicans who have indicated they may vote in favor of new testimony—about whether Mr. Trump could assure the nation he wouldn't direct private citizens such as Mr. Giuliani to carry out foreign policy without a formal designation, Mr. Philbin replied: "I want to make clear that there was no conduct of foreign policy being carried out here by a private person."
That is sharply at odds with testimony House investigators heard in the fall. Several witnesses testified that Mr. Trump directed administration officials to work with Mr. Giuliani, who doesn't hold an official position, on resolving his concerns about Ukraine before he would agree to a meeting with the new Ukrainian president. State Department officials periodically reached out to Mr. Giuliani to ensure they were giving the new Ukrainian administration the proper messages to satisfy Mr. Giuliani's concerns.
Mr. Schiff called the assertion "startling." He noted that the president's lawyers have argued that critics of Mr. Trump's dealings with Ukraine objected to his policy, not his conduct. "They have now acknowledged that the person in charge of this was not conducting policy," Mr. Schiff said.
Democrats also tangled with the president's legal team on Thursday over a controversial theory raised a day earlier by Trump lawyer Alan Dershowitz: that because Mr. Trump believes his re-election is in the public interest, even if he had political motivations in pressing Ukraine to open an investigation into the Bidens, it wouldn't be impeachable.
"What we have seen over the last couple days is a descent into constitutional madness," Mr. Schiff said.
Mr. Dershowitz wasn't present for Thursday's session. On Twitter, he clarified his remarks, saying a president's lawful behavior couldn't "be turned into a criminal or impeachable offense just because it was motivated in part by electoral considerations."
Related Coverage
*
Live Coverage of Trump's Impeachment Trial

*
Trial Offers Hints on Where Senators Stand on Witnesses

*
White House Says John Bolton's Manuscript Can't Be Published As Is

*
Where Things Stand in the Trump Impeachment Trial—and What's Next

*
Sen. Collins's Focused Approach Could Help Alter Impeachment Trial

*
Six Days in the Senate: How Democrats, Trump Team Tried the Impeachment Case

Democratic House managers, acting as prosecutors, are arguing that senators should convict Mr. Trump for abusing his power by withholding nearly $400 million in U.S. military aid to Ukraine as leverage for the country to open investigations that would aid his re-election efforts. The aid was ultimately released under bipartisan pressure from Congress. The House managers also accuse Mr. Trump of trying to cover up his alleged misconduct by obstructing congressional investigations into the matter. Mr. Trump has denied any wrongdoing.
Ms. Collins, along with a handful of other senators, on Thursday asked Democrats whether there were legitimate circumstances under which a president could ask a foreign country to investigate a U.S. citizen—including a political rival—who wasn't under investigation by the U.S.
"It would be hard to contemplate circumstances where that's appropriate," Mr. Schiff responded. Mr. Philbin said it was legitimate for the president to ask for a foreign investigation into a matter where a U.S. citizen broke the law abroad.
Andrew Duehren and Natalie Andrews contributed to this article.
Write to Rebecca Ballhaus at
Rebecca.Ballhaus@wsj.com
, Lindsay Wise at
lindsay.wise@wsj.com
and Siobhan Hughes at
siobhan.hughes@wsj.com

title: U.S., China Sign Deal Easing Trade Tensions; Agreement aims to sharply increase sales of U.S. goods and services to China, help protect intellectual property and further open Chinese markets
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON—The U.S. and China signed
a trade deal
that officials say will lead to a sharp increase in sales of U.S. goods and services to China, further open Chinese markets to foreign firms—especially in financial services—and provide strong new protections for trade secrets and intellectual property.

The eight-part agreement
acts as a cease-fire in a two-year trade war that has roiled markets world-wide and cut into global growth. But it leaves in place U.S. tariffs on about $370 billion in Chinese goods, or about three-quarters of Chinese imports to the U.S.
Possible tariff reductions will be left to later negotiations, which will cover a host of difficult issues at the heart of the trade battle, including Chinese subsidies to domestic companies and Beijing's oversight of Chinese state-owned firms. Those talks are expected to begin fairly soon but not conclude until after the U.S. presidential election in November.
Speaking to a packed audience of business and political leaders in the East Room of the White House, President Trump said the remaining tariffs "will all come off" if the talks produce a second agreement. He called the deal a "momentous step—one that has never been taken before with China—toward a future of fair and reciprocal trade."
Vice Premier Liu He of China, who signed the agreement for Beijing, played up the need for both countries to act together to tackle challenges such as terrorism, aging and environmental protection.
SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS
What would you like to see in the next phase of the trade deal between the U.S. and China? Join the conversation below.
"China has established a political system and an economic-development model that suits its own characteristics," Mr. Liu said. "But that doesn't mean China and the U.S. can't work together."
While the deal contains wins for the U.S., the fact that most tariffs will remain on Chinese imports clouds prospects for growth in business investment between the two countries, said John Frisbie, a China expert at the trade consulting firm of Hills & Co.
"Overall uncertainty is not reduced much because there is no removal of existing tariffs [and] questions whether China can buy the quantities of goods and services the administration wants," he said.
U.S. stocks have surged since the countries said they were nearing a deal, and the Dow Jones Industrial Average closed above 29000 for the first time on Wednesday. But market reaction to the actual signing was muted, suggesting investors saw little that was surprising within the text of the agreement.
"Basically, we've been told repeatedly that this deal was done," said Mike O'Rourke, chief market strategist at JonesTrading.
The Republican president sees the trade deal as a win politically going into the November election. The president can laud the agreement and argue that he is the only one who can successfully press Beijing for more concessions. "President Trump saw an opportunity to advance the U.S. positioning at a time when the Chinese are seeing great political and economic turbulence," said Jason Miller, a former Trump campaign spokesman.
Democrats have been critical of the deal. Former Vice President Joe Biden, who is running for the Democratic presidential nomination, made clear that he wasn't going to cede the issue to Mr. Trump. He criticized many of the pact's provisions as "vague, weak, or covered by previous announcements and existing agreements."
The agreement is structured as one between equals, but Beijing is making nearly all the changes in policy and purchases. The pact focuses heavily on U.S. complaints that the Chinese government and companies coerce U.S. ones into handing over their technology to their rivals, and Mr. Trump's focus on trying to close the vast trade deficit with China.
Beijing has denied it engages in coercion and has, in the past, pledged to make sure no pressure is applied. The two pages on technology transfer go beyond other agreements China has signed that dealt with that issue.
"Neither party shall require or pressure persons" to transfer technology to do business or to get regulatory approvals, the agreement said. The deal also banned pressure "formally or informally" on companies to use a certain technology to get a license.
However, the section doesn't require China to change any law or regulation to fulfill its obligations. A draft agreement that fell apart in May required dozens of changes in Chinese law. Top officials in Beijing nixed that deal, and the U.S. negotiators sought to retain as much of the tentative deal as possible. The deal is written in legalese and trade jargon that will be pored over by trade experts and lawyers.
As a condition of Beijing signing the deal, the U.S.
agreed to cut tariffs
on $120 billion in Chinese goods by half, to 7.5%, within about 30 days, and to forgo other planned tariffs. None of those commitments are part of the text.
In the intellectual-property section, China agreed to stiffen protection of trade secrets and to assess criminal penalties for "willful trade secret misappropriation." Increasing penalties was a priority of Mr. Trump's administration. But much of the intellectual-property language was light on specific rules in new areas. The pharmaceutical portion didn't include specific targets and didn't have language about defending biologic drugs from generic imitators, a major goal of big U.S. drugmakers.
The agreement also requires China to act quickly to accept applications from bank cards and payments systems seeking to access the Chinese market, and the deal's text cites Mastercard, Visa and American Express by name. The U.S. had previously fought cases at the World Trade Organization to win access for U.S. payment providers, but China hasn't followed through with permitting access to the firms in all cases.
The U.S. also pledged to continue to open its market to China's UnionPay system.
The provisions of the deal are subject to an enforcement mechanism that calls for several rounds of consultations. If the two sides don't reach an agreement, the complaining party could take "remedial measure in a proportionate way"—trade lingo for reimposing tariffs. In practice, the U.S. would likely be the party bringing the complaint because it is China that is pledging to make changes and increase purchases.
So long as the tariff imposition is in good faith, Beijing agreed not to retaliate. But the good-faith and proportionality requirements give China a lot of room to act. Rather than retaliate with tariffs, the deal says the party whose actions led to the complaint could withdraw from the deal—although then China would be free to retaliate. A senior U.S. administration official said he figured Beijing would be very reluctant to take such steps, which would shatter the deal.
But it is unclear whether U.S. companies, wary of retaliation by China, will refer disputes to the enforcement mechanism. Most trade deals use arbitration panels to settle disputes, figuring they can be impartial.
"There is a strong element of Yogi Berra's quip about déjà vu all over again," said James Green, a former U.S. trade negotiator in Beijing under Mr. Trump. "The dispute resolution section will have the same problem we've always faced—U.S. companies are reluctant to become poster children for market access problems or discriminatory treatment."
The biggest section of the deal covers Chinese purchases. Beijing pledged to buy an additional $200 billion in goods and split across 2020 and 2021, with the deal calling for $77 billion in additional trade the first year and $123 billion the second year.
Across the two years, the targets call for China to boost its purchasing above the levels seen in 2017, by about $78 billion in manufacturing, by an extra $32 billion of agriculture, by $52 billion of energy and by $38 billion of services. The deal said targets have been agreed on for narrower categories of items, but these targets weren't disclosed, the administration said, to avoid distorting markets.
In 2017, the U.S. exported $186 billion of goods and services. To fulfill the targets in the deal, U.S. exports to China would need to climb to $263 billion in 2020 and $309 billion in 2021, an increase without precedent in the history of U.S. trade.
U.S.-China Deal at a Glance
Here is what you need to know about the 90-page first phase of the trade deal.
*
Buying American: Beijing will ramp up purchases of U.S. goods and services by $200 billion over the next two years, using 2017 as a benchmark. This includes increased purchases of manufactured goods by $77.7 billion over the two-year period. The category of tech services, which includes charges for cloud computing-related services and the use of intellectual property, is projected to grow by $37.9 billion. Energy purchases will increase by $52.4 billion under the deal.
*
Agriculture Purchases: The much-touted agriculture purchases have smaller goals for increased trade under the deal than energy, manufacturing and services, with an increase of $32 billion over the two-year period. In addition to the purchase targets, however, China has agreed to steps that allow more market access for U.S. dairy products, poultry, beef, fish, rice and even pet food.
*
Trade Secrets: The deal includes strong language related to preventing and punishing theft of trade secrets. The deal makes it easier for U.S. businesses to persuade authorities to initiate a criminal investigation in China. In addition, the deal says U.S. businesses operating in China should be able to operate "openly and freely" without pressure to transfer their technology to foreign business partners. Sharing tech blueprints "must be based on market terms that are voluntary and reflect mutual agreement," it said.
*
Financial Services: The deal removes barriers to help U.S. banking institutions, insurers and other financial-services companies expand in the Chinese market. That includes quickly reviewing license applications from credit-card companies and U.S.-owned credit-rating services. The deal sets a five-month deadline for China to allow branches of U.S. financial institutions to provide securities investment-fund custody services.
*
Resolving Business Disputes: The deal calls for the creation of a dispute-resolution office, addressing longstanding complaints from the U.S. business community that their disagreements with Chinese partners haven't been fairly resolved. It laid out the framework for officials in U.S. and China to discuss how to implement this mechanism, including information sharing and an appeals process.
*
Tariff Relief: Prior to the deal, the U.S. agreed to cut the tariff rate to 7.5% from 15% for charges it had imposed on roughly $120 billion in Chinese products. The U.S. also held off on tariffs of 15% on roughly $156 billion in consumer products, including smartphones, that were set to take effect in December. The deal doesn't amend that prior agreement. President Trump on Wednesday said he would remove the tariffs if the next round of negotiations are successful.
*
Currency Manipulation: China commits not to devalue its currency or make persistent intervention in its currency market. China also commits to a schedule of regular disclosures of data regarding its foreign-exchange holdings.
—Katy Stech Ferek
The projected steep climb in exports left some potential beneficiaries skeptical. For instance, Mr. Liu said the purchases wouldn't come at the expense of other countries. That could make it harder for Beijing to meet the purchase goals.
The deal also has some terms that China could use to claim that the U.S. is at fault if it doesn't meet the purchase targets. For instance, China could request consultations if China's purchases are "affected by an action or inaction by the United States," the text says. That could come into play if U.S. export rules limit the technology products the U.S. lets China buy.
A senior administration official said the provision just allows for discussions and wouldn't be a basis for China to claim it can't fulfill its commitments.
Alex Leary, Sam Goldfarb, Austen Hufford and Josh Zumbrun contributed to this article.
More
*
Businesses Laud Deal, Want Tariffs to End

*
Heard on the Street: Trade Détente, but a More Dangerous World

*
Analysis: No Trade Peace for Chips Yet

Write to Bob Davis at
bob.davis@wsj.com
, Lingling Wei at
lingling.wei@wsj.com
and William Mauldin at
william.mauldin@wsj.com
