title: In Iowa, Biden Tries to Turn Impeachment Trial to His Advantage; Former vice president points to Republican efforts to damage him as sign of his resilience.
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
CLINTON, Iowa—Before President Trump, no American president had ever sought re-election in the middle of
an impeachment
.
Former Vice President Joe Biden is contending with a similar distinction in the Democratic primaries, as a White House candidate caught up in the impeachment of Mr. Trump, whose trial centers around his pressing Ukraine to investigate Mr. Biden, a possible opponent in this year's election.
Days before
the Iowa caucuses
, Mr. Biden is trying to turn Republican efforts to damage him in the impeachment trial into a badge of honor and a sign of his resilience. His campaign hopes it will help him appeal to Democratic voters struggling to answer the contest's biggest question: Which Democrat is best positioned to defeat Mr. Trump in November's general election?
"This whole impeachment trial for Trump is just a political hit job to smear me," Mr. Biden told an audience Tuesday night in Clinton, a community along the Mississippi River. "That's how scared Trump is about having to run against me."
In a sign of his push to show he's the most electable Democrat, Mr. Biden planned to deliver an address Thursday to supporters in Waukee, a suburb of Des Moines, that would directly take on the president and serve as a prebuttal to Mr. Trump's evening rally at Drake University.
When Iowa Republican Sen. Joni Ernst suggested the Senate's trial in Washington could undercut Mr. Biden's appeal in Iowa, his campaign quickly seized upon her comments and posted a digital ad.
Mr. Trump's lawyers argued this week that the president was justified in seeking investigations into Mr. Biden and his son, Hunter Biden, who served on the board of the Ukrainian natural gas company Burisma while Mr. Biden was vice president. Mr. Biden has said he did nothing wrong in pressuring Ukraine to fire a prosecutor who had at one time been involved in investigating Burisma and who was widely viewed as
insufficiently aggressive on corruption
. Mr. Biden has also noted he was carrying out the Obama administration's Ukraine policy, which was in line with international partners on rooting out corruption.
A career State Department official told lawmakers last year that he
raised concerns in 2015
about Hunter Biden's position at Burisma, which he thought could appear to be a conflict of interest. According to one official with ties to the company, Hunter Biden's compensation was around $50,000 a month.
Hunter Biden has said
that he showed "poor judgment" in joining the board but that he only discussed his work with Burisma with his father once.
Mr. Biden rarely hears questions from voters about the impeachment trial. But the uncertainty over how long it will last has loomed over the final week in Iowa.
Sens. Bernie Sanders, Elizabeth Warren and Amy Klobuchar have been forced to scrap most of their Iowa campaign schedules to attend the trial. (A fourth senator running for president, Michael Bennet of Colorado, has focused his long-shot bid on New Hampshire).
The
possibility of testimony
at the impeachment trial from witnesses, such as former national security adviser John Bolton, could mean the proceeding spills over into campaigning ahead of the Feb. 11 New Hampshire primary.
It also could increase the likelihood that Mr. Biden's son, or even Mr. Biden himself, might be called to testify. The former vice president has rejected suggestions of an exchange involving Mr. Bolton and others for his own testimony or that of his son.
He told reporters this week that he had "nothing to defend. This is all a game."
Republicans, meanwhile, haven't been subtle about trying to use the trial to undermine Mr. Biden's candidacy.
Ms. Ernst, who is seeking re-election this year, told reporters on Capitol Hill that she was "really interested" to see how the arguments made by Mr. Trump's legal team "informs and influences the Iowa caucus voters."
Mr. Biden pounced, reading aloud the senator's comments during his events in Iowa. The campaign placed a homemade sign on the wall that said, "Joni—We're w/ Joe."
"She spilled the beans," said Mr. Biden, who told his supporters, "You can ruin Donald Trump's night by caucusing for me, but also you can ruin Joni Ernst's night."
One of Ms. Ernst's Senate colleagues, meanwhile, bought airtime in Iowa to bolster
Mr. Trump's defense
. Sen. Rick Scott (R., Fla.) cut a 30-second ad accusing Mr. Biden of getting away with a pressure campaign against Ukraine and helping his son profit from his position, charges the Bidens and supporters have denied.

This Year's Iowa Caucuses Are Different. Here's How They'll Work.

"I just see that as part of the desperation of the Republicans in facing him, that they've got to try to drag him and his son into this," said Jeff Hermiston, a retired teacher from West Liberty, Iowa, who saw Mr. Biden at a recent event and plans to caucus for him. "I realize it's peripheral to the issue, but it's not the issue."
Mr. Biden has tried to turn the GOP criticism into a sign of his strength as a candidate and his ability to move past such drama. "I hope I've demonstrated that I can take a punch," he said in Cedar Falls, Iowa.
Write to Ken Thomas at
ken.thomas@wsj.com

title: Trump Says Parts of U.S. Could Go Back to Work in a Few Weeks; White House weighs proposing workplace coronavirus testing, but capacity remains limited; governors suggest they will go their own way
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit





A business closing in the Fordham Heights section of the Bronx borough in New York City this past weekend. PHOTO: Kholood Eid for The Wall Street Journal
WASHINGTON—President Trump said restrictions on economic activity could be lifted in some parts of the country but not others as his administration works to develop a plan for how Americans could return to work in a few weeks without exacerbating
the spread of the new coronavirus in the U.S.

"It's time. People want to get back to work," Mr. Trump said in a briefing Wednesday. He said that "large sections" of the country could return to work far sooner than others, but that New York has a 'number of very tough weeks ahead." The president added that "I'm not going to do anything rash or hastily."
Mr. Trump in recent days has repeatedly signaled his interest in reviving the economy within the coming weeks,
saying Tuesday that he hoped to do so by Easter
, which falls on April 12—just under a month after the White House issued guidelines advising Americans to practice social distancing and avoid gathering in groups of 10 or more.
But the federal government's ability to force the reopening of the economy is limited, as much of that power rests with state governors and mayors.
Mr. Trump's timeline also is considerably shorter than what many health experts, including some in his own administration, have said will be necessary to blunt the spread of coronavirus across the U.S. and keep the nation's health care system from being overwhelmed.
The president claimed in a tweet Wednesday that the news media was pressuring him to keep much of the economy closed to hurt his re-election chances in November.
White House advisers and public health experts are developing proposals that could include workplace testing of employees and intensified contact tracing to curb the spread of the infection, according to people familiar with the planning. Their goal is to release a plan before Easter. Officials are also considering implementing more widespread and targeted testing in areas of the country where there are fewer cases.
But it isn't clear the U.S. currently has the testing capacity to implement such measures. State and local health labs would need more federal help to establish specific reporting sites that act as sentinels to know how fast or far the virus is spreading.
Even if Mr. Trump moves to relax the federal government's social distancing guidelines next month, his actions may have a limited effect.
While the Trump administration has issued guidelines urging Americans to stay home, the most severe restrictions nationwide have come from governors, who have ordered nonessential businesses to close in at least 24 states and have imposed restrictions on those businesses in a dozen more. Nineteen states plan to or already require residents to stay home. Federal guidelines don't trump state restrictions.
The result could be an even further decentralized patchwork of guidelines across the nation, which public-health experts say will make it harder to combat the virus's spread. The U.S., because of its decentralized structure of government and health care systems, has faced greater hurdles than some Asian countries in implementing rigorous measures to test and quarantine citizens.
"A patchwork approach is functionally a least-common-denominator approach, which is a huge problem," said Jeremy Konyndyk, who led the U.S. government's response to international disasters under the Obama administration. "In the absence of uniform standards and robust surveillance, we are vulnerable to governors taking risks in their states that end up endangering other states as well."
White House spokesman Judd Deere said the administration is "evaluating critical data to determine next steps" and that the president remains in close contact with governors. "The goal is for America to be healthy, prosperous, and again open for business, and we remain committed to reaching that goal in partnership with state and local leaders," he said.
Mr. Trump has faced pressure from business leaders and some of his own advisers to reopen the economy soon, as uncertainty about the pandemic has sent the stock market reeling in recent weeks, and
business closures have caused millions to lose their jobs
. "We can't have the cure be worse than the problem," Mr. Trump said this week.
Health experts in the administration have urged more caution. Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, has said it will be at least several weeks before the country can reopen and on Tuesday described the Easter timeline as "flexible."
Governors in both parties rejected the Easter timeline the president offered and said they planned to chart their own course. Democratic New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo, whose state has been by far the hardest hit by the virus, stressed that the federal government was offering suggestions, not decrees. "They call them guidelines because they are guidelines," he said at a briefing Wednesday. "We'll come up with a plan that works for New York."
Democratic California Gov. Gavin Newsom, who last week ordered the state's 40 million residents to stay at home except for essential activities, said it would be "misleading to represent" that California would reopen by Easter.
Ohio Gov. Mike DeWine, a Republican, tweeted that he was looking forward to the day when the economy could reopen, but "it's not yet here."
Some states have also imposed penalties for violating state guidelines aimed at slowing the virus's spread. In Virginia, companies can lose operating licenses or face misdemeanor charges if they violate state guidelines. Oregon Gov. Kate Brown, a Democrat, made it a misdemeanor to open or shop at certain retail businesses such as hair salons, gyms and fitness studios and theaters.
Public health experts say it could take months, if not years, before life returns to normal. They say the U.S. is woefully behind on the type of widespread testing and quarantine measures adopted in Singapore and South Korea that were successful at reducing spread of the virus. They also say that reopening too soon could overwhelm hospitals, endanger health-care workers and fuel the virus's spread in states where it isn't prevalent now.
Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, director-general of the World Health Organization, warned in a briefing Wednesday that in the absence of necessary preparations, the virus could resurge once restrictions are eased. "The last thing any country needs is to open schools and businesses, only to be forced to close them again because of a resurgence," he said.
Another question is the level of control the president can exert over the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's guidelines. Mr. Trump has stressed that he will listen to advice from his administration's health experts on when to reopen the economy, but that he will render the final decision on the timeline.
Ned Price, who was an adviser to former President Barack Obama, said that while Mr. Trump has authority over CDC guidelines, the agency has traditionally been granted a level of independence by previous presidents. That practice, however, is dictated "not by laws but by norms," which Mr. Trump has made a habit of shattering, he said.
Americans around the country in recent days received a postcard from the federal government outlining the CDC's guidelines for social distancing. The front of the postcard reads: "President Trump's coronavirus guidelines for America." His first piece of advice: "Listen and follow the directions of your STATE AND LOCAL AUTHORITIES."
Christine Mai-Duc and Jimmy Vielkind contributed to this article.
WSJ Newsletter
Get an early-morning coronavirus briefing each weekday, plus a health-news update Fridays:
Sign up here.

Rebecca.Ballhaus@wsj.com
and Stephanie Armour at
stephanie.armour@wsj.com

title: National Security Adviser Discounts Reports of Russian Interference to Help Re-elect Trump; 'There's no briefing that I've received, that the president has received, that says that President Putin is doing anything to try and influence the elections in favor of President Trump,' Robert O'Brien said
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
National security adviser Robert O'Brien sought to use a series of television interviews broadcast Sunday to rebut reports that the Russian government is trying to help President Trump be re-elected.
"There's no briefing that I've received, that the president has received, that says that President Putin is doing anything to try and influence the elections in favor of President Trump," Mr. O'Brien said on the CBS News program "Face the Nation." "I've seen no intelligence along those lines."
But Mr. O'Brien appeared to choose his words carefully and didn't dispute news reports that Shelby Pierson, the top election security official for the director of national intelligence, had briefed the House Intelligence Committee last week that Russia appear to
have a preference for Mr. Trump
in the 2020 presidential race.
Mr. O'Brien didn't deny that Russia is using social media and other means to interfere in the U.S. election process with the aim of exacerbating the tensions in American society.
"The Russians have always tried to interfere with elections because they want to divide Americans," he said.
Concerns have mounted in recent weeks among Democratic lawmakers that Russia is trying to involve itself in U.S. presidential politics to boost Mr. Trump's prospects, much as the U.S. intelligence community and Special Counsel Robert Mueller
concluded Moscow did
in 2016.
Mr. Trump has denied that Russia played a role in getting him elected in 2016 and said there is no proof that he or his campaign attempted to collude with the Kremlin.
While playing down reports alleging Russian support for Mr. Trump, Mr. O'Brien confirmed accounts that
Russia is seeking to help Sen. Bernie Sanders
win the Democratic nomination
"What I've heard from the FBI…is that Russia would like Bernie Sanders to win the Democrat nomination," Mr. O'Brien said. "They'd probably like him to be president, understandably, because he wants to spend money on social programs and probably would have to take it out of the military."
Mr. O'Brien also appeared on ABC's "This Week" with George Stephanopoulos on Sunday.
Some political analysts say that Russia favors Mr. Sanders's nomination because Russian officials calculate that he would be the weakest opponent as Mr. Trump seeks re-election and because each man is a polarizing figure for many Americans.
Sen. Chris Murphy, a Connecticut Democrat, criticized Mr. O'Brien for his remarks about Mr. Sanders.
"Our national security adviser should stay out of politics," Mr. Murphy said on the CNN "State of the Union" news program. "What I am worried about is the politicization of intelligence by this administration."
Mr. Sanders has said that he was warned by U.S. officials that Russia is trying to assist his campaign and he has urged Russia to stay out of the election.

title: Pompeo Insists He Has No Senate Plans, Though GOP Operatives Think Otherwise; Some think he is weighing a bid to replace retiring Republican Sen. Pat Roberts
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON—Secretary of State Mike Pompeo reiterated on Monday that he has no plans to run next year for U.S. Senate. Still, Republican strategists say they're increasingly convinced that he will eventually jump in.
"It's my intention to stay and continue to serve as President Trump's Secretary of State," Mr. Pompeo said Monday on Fox News, adding: "I've said that consistently."
Asked if he was ruling out a run, he responded: "I've watched my life take turns that one would never have expected. But it's not something I want to do."
Mr. Pompeo's multiple trips to Kansas in 2019 stirred rumors that he might be weighing a Senate bid to succeed Republican Sen. Pat Roberts,
who is retiring
. Mr. Pompeo continued to stoke speculation this month with the creation of personal Twitter and Instagram accounts. Among the first photos Mr. Pompeo posted on the new Twitter feed was a picture of him meeting with members of the Kansas Farm Bureau, a crucial constituent group for a prospective candidate.
The social media accounts appeared a few weeks after President Trump opened the door to a possible Senate run by Mr. Pompeo, saying in November that he was confident Mr. Pompeo would "
easily win in Kansas
" if he ran. The comments marked a shift for Mr. Trump, who had previously been chilly to the idea of Mr. Pompeo leaving the cabinet for the Senate.
"Every single possible signal is that he's running: trips to the state, Trump openly discussing his replacement, engaged operatives," said Jeff Roe, a GOP strategist who has run statewide, congressional and caucus races in Kansas.
"The only thing left is to hit send on the yard sign order," Mr. Roe said.
"Actions speak louder than words, and the Secretary's recent actions paint a clear picture that he is considering a run for Senate," said one national Republican operative. "It's going to be on his terms and on his own timeline, but there is
a growing belief that it's merely a matter of time
before he announces."
National security adviser Robert O'Brien told ABC's "This Week" on Sunday that he hoped Mr. Pompeo didn't leave. He said he'd spoken with Mr. Pompeo recently and that Mr. Pompeo had told him he's not running for Senate.
Mr. Pompeo has plenty of time to announce a run. The filing deadline in Kansas isn't until June, ahead of the GOP primary in August. And he has nearly $1 million sitting in his dormant federal campaign account that he could use for a Senate run, under federal election rules.
Mr. Pompeo grew up in California, but moved to Kansas in the 1990s. A former businessman and Army officer, he served three terms as a congressman representing Wichita, Kan., before President Trump appointed him to lead the Central Intelligence Agency and then the State Department.
Write to Lindsay Wise at
lindsay.wise@wsj.com

title: Trump Says He Will Release Middle East Peace Plan Before Israeli Leaders Visit; Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, rival Benny Gantz set to come to White House next week
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
TEL AVIV—President Trump said Thursday he likely would make public his administration's long-delayed plan for peace in the Middle East—under development since 2017—before a visit to Washington next week by Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his main political rival, Benny Gantz.
The two Israeli political leaders accepted a U.S. invitation to discuss the peace plan during a visit to Jerusalem by Vice President Mike Pence.
Mr. Trump said he also has spoken briefly to the Palestinians, and said U.S. officials would speak further to them. Mr. Trump has taken a series of steps during his administration considered favorable to the Israelis, including recognizing Jerusalem as Israel's capital, slashing bilateral assistance to the Palestinians and backing Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank.
"I'm sure they [Palestinians] maybe will react negatively at first but it's actually very positive for them," Mr. Trump told reporters aboard Air Force One en route to Florida on Thursday.
Mr. Trump and others on his team have committed to time frames to release the plan before, only later to back away from them. Palestinian officials had cut off all contact with the Trump administration in late 2017, when Mr. Trump said he would move the U.S. embassy to Jerusalem.
The White House is considering making its peace plan public before Israel's March vote to try to get ahead of the U.S. election season and as political support in Israel grows for the release of the political blueprint.
The White House wouldn't say whether it invited Palestinian officials, but they are not expected to attend.
"This step only reaffirms our absolute rejection of what the U.S. administration has done so far," said Husam Zomlot, who was the Palestinians' ambassador to Washington before the U.S. closed the Palestinian mission in 2018. He is now the ambassador to the U.K.
In Jerusalem, Mr. Pence said Mr. Netanyahu and Mr. Gantz accepted President Trump's invitation.
SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS
Should the White House release its peace plan before Israeli elections? Join the conversation below.
"We very much look forward to [welcoming] you to our nation's capital to continue discussions about a broad range of issues of mutual concerns between the United States and Israel but also about the prospect of peace," Mr. Pence said.
Mr. Netanyahu said he suggested including Mr. Gantz "because I think it's important we do not lose this historic opportunity with such friends in the White House."
The White House formally announced the visit shortly after Mr. Pence's comments. The visit, on Jan. 28, is the same day Israel's parliament will begin the process of forming a panel that will debate Mr. Netanyahu's
request for immunity
from charges of bribery, fraud and breach of trust.
The charges stem from allegations
that he traded official favors for flattering news coverage, as well as gifts worth hundreds of thousands of dollars, including pink champagne, cigars and jewelry.
If the panel is formed before the March vote, as is expected, Mr. Netanyahu likely will see his immunity request denied, though his Likud party is trying to delay the process.
Mr. Trump's Mideast peace team, headed by his son-in-law Jared Kushner, is concerned that the window before Israel's ballot could be the last opportunity to release the blueprint before the U.S. election season, according to people familiar with the matter. The coming vote in Israel might again be inconclusive, followed by months more of political wrangling to set up an Israeli government.
Mr. Netanyahu failed after April and September elections
to form a governing coalition
, and Israel faces an unprecedented third vote in less than a year as the political deadlock continues. He remains the head of a caretaker government during the impasse.
Mr. Netanyahu has welcomed the U.S. plan, describing it as an opportunity for Israel to
annex parts of the West Bank
under a supportive administration in Washington.
Mr. Gantz also has warmed to having the plan released before the election. He initially harbored concerns that it could work to Mr. Netanyahu's advantage.
Mr. Kushner had intended to travel to Israel to meet with Messrs. Netanyahu and Gantz on the sidelines of a Holocaust forum in Jerusalem after conversations with Arab officials at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, but he canceled the trip at the last minute, citing bad weather.
Mr. Trump tapped Mr. Kushner to work on the Mideast peace plan in 2016, before taking office, and the administration has repeatedly delayed its release. Administration officials
presented a Mideast economic plan
in Bahrain in June, but it was seen as impossible to implement without a political component and none of the promised follow-up summits to sign off on the document have been held.
The administration also has been counting on support for its plan from Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, but the crown prince's
international stature was weakened
following the 2018 killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi at a Saudi consulate in Turkey.
Mr. Netanyahu has tried to position himself as the best person to negotiate a deal, and the plan's release could give his candidacy a boost, analysts said. But it could also make it harder for him to win the support of political parties to his right, whose support he will need in a coalition.
Meanwhile, the release could also spark protests or heighten tensions between the U.S. and regional Arab allies if it is interpreted as too favorable to Israel.
Mr. Zomlat, the Palestinian official, said the Palestinians would reject any deal that doesn't include East Jerusalem as the capital of a Palestinian state and an end to Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza.
Mr. Netanyahu has pledged to unilaterally
annex the Jordan Valley
if he is re-elected and called for the parliament to vote on the matter as early as next week. Mr. Gantz said on Tuesday that he would look to do the same by seeking consensus in Israel and with the help of the international community. American officials said they oppose any unilateral actions before the plan is released.
Israel's struggles to elect a government have added to the challenge facing any peace initiative, leaving unclear when an elected Israeli leader will emerge to take up any negotiations that spring from the plan.
Jason Greenblatt, Mr. Trump's original Middle East peace envoy,
left his job
late last year as the plan's release kept sliding amid Israel's political deadlock.
More than six months after releasing its
economic plan for the area
, U.S. officials have maintained a close hold on the political portion of the document. More than 50 pages long, it envisions that no Israelis or Palestinians in the West Bank will leave their homes and it would move Israel's border east of the internationally accepted Green Line with the West Bank, U.S. officials have said.
That, veteran peace negotiators say, indicates that the Trump plan is likely a sharp departure from past efforts that left many of the sensitive details—such as the final status of Jerusalem and security arrangements—for later talks and envisioned land swaps to resolve one of the key issues of the conflict: precise borders and what will be done with Israeli settlements.
While the Trump administration hopes the document can be a basis for serious negotiations, experts said meaningful talks will remain a challenge, even if the plan defies expectations and garners some Arab support. The unsettled Israeli political situation is exacerbated by the continuing split among Palestinians, between Hamas in Gaza and the Palestinian Authority in the West Bank.
"You lack leaders who are masters of their political houses on either side, and who are willing to take the risk of venturing out," said Aaron David Miller, a senior fellow at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace and former negotiator and State Department analyst.
Dov Lieber in Tel Aviv and Alex Leary in Washington contributed to this article.
Write to Felicia Schwartz at
Felicia.Schwartz@wsj.com

title: Trump Uses Campaign Rally to Wade Into Democratic Debate; The president told supporters in Milwaukee that Bernie Sanders was 'surging' and that Democrats were 'wasting their time' with impeachment
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
MILWAUKEE—As six Democratic candidates faced off in Iowa on Tuesday evening, President Trump, less than 400 miles away, sought to insert himself into the process at a rally for his reelection campaign.
Former Vice President Joe Biden? "Sleepy." Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren? "Not going anywhere."
But Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders? "Surging."
Trump campaign aides and political allies view Mr. Sanders, a self-declared socialist, as an easier opponent than other potential contenders. Mr. Trump has tweeted about Mr. Sanders twice this week, saying on Sunday that he was "looking very good" and stoking the
clash between the two leading liberals
in the race. "Elizabeth is very angry at Bernie. Do I see a feud brewing?" he
tweeted
Monday.
Mr. Sanders has
ticked up in recent national polls
, but is separated from Messrs. Biden and Warren by a few percentage points. Unlike Mr. Biden, Mr. Sanders has never polled above 30% among Democrats nationally in this election cycle.
The president also sided with Mr. Sanders in a growing clash between him and Ms. Warren over whether the Vermont senator told Ms. Warren in a 2018 meeting that he didn't believe a woman could win the election. Mr. Warren confirmed that characterization after it was reported by CNN; Mr. Sanders has denied it.
"I don't believe that he said this," Mr. Trump told a packed arena in Milwaukee. "I don't particularly like him, the nasty guy, but…[it's] not the kind of thing he'd say."
Mr. Trump had low expectations for the Democrats' face-off. "Nobody is watching," he said. "They haven't been doing great on the debates, I have to tell you."
Mr. Trump also sought to create a split screen between his actions as president and Democrats' efforts to oust him from office, a strategy that campaign aides have said they intend to pursue over the course of the election year.
"While we're creating jobs and killing terrorists, Democrats in Congress are wasting America's time with demented, hoaxes and crazy witch hunts," the president said.
The House is set to vote Wednesday to name impeachment managers and send the articles of impeachment to the Senate. Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R., Ky.) said he expects to
start the president's impeachment trial next Tuesday
, when Mr. Trump is scheduled to be in Davos, Switzerland, for the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum.
Tuesday's rally marked the president's second of the election year and his first time in Wisconsin since July, when he traveled to Milwaukee to give a speech on trade.
Wisconsin, a state Mr. Trump won in 2016 by fewer than 23,000 votes, is a key battleground in the 2020 race. Top Democrats had already collectively t
raveled to the state 10 times
by September, and Wisconsin is one of four states where a top Democratic group, Priorities USA, plans to spend $150 million before the convention this summer in Milwaukee.
The Trump campaign has also signaled it plans to make Wisconsin a priority. Lara Trump, a senior adviser to the campaign and the president's daughter-in-law, traveled there for an event Monday. Jared Kushner, a senior White House adviser and the president's son-in-law, was also in Milwaukee on Tuesday for a criminal justice event.
Write to Rebecca Ballhaus at
Rebecca.Ballhaus@wsj.com

title: Moderate Democrats Stress Over Crowded Center Lane; There is no single centrist rival to front-runner Bernie Sanders, and party leaders are bracing for a protracted nomination fight
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit





From left: Michael Bloomberg, Sen. Amy Klobuchar, Pete Buttigieg and Joe Biden. PHOTO: Photo Illustration: WSJ; Photos: Gabriela Bhaskar for The Wall Street Journal, Associated Press (3)
NASHUA, N.H.—Democrats in search of a centrist nominee to challenge President Trump are increasingly worried after contests in
Iowa
and
New Hampshire
consolidated liberal support behind Bernie Sanders and divided the larger moderate vote among multiple candidates.
The party's center lane is crowded with the rising former South Bend, Ind., Mayor Pete Buttigieg, Sen. Amy Klobuchar and former Vice President Joe Biden. Looming in the
March 3 Super Tuesday states
and beyond is former New York Mayor Mike Bloomberg, buoyed by
campaign spending that dwarfs all his opponents combined
.
With no clear centrist front-runner, vulnerable freshman Democrats in Congress are texting each other anxiously, a Biden-allied fundraiser warns of a "doomsday scenario" and party strategists fret about what mixed early-state turnout means for November.
Predictions about which candidates are the most electable and which will prevail through a long primary season have proven unreliable in the past, particularly at this early stage of the process, before voting in the diverse states of South Carolina and Nevada. Barack Obama faced intraparty doubts in 2008, as did Mr. Trump in 2016.
With multiple contenders vowing to stay in the race, party leaders are yet again bracing for the likelihood of a protracted fight for the nomination that may not be settled by the time of the July convention in Milwaukee.
Adding to some Democrats' worries is the president's
acquittal from impeachment
and his strength among his most fervent supporters, as evidenced by the more than 11,000 who turned out for his
Monday night rally in Manchester, N.H.
, a larger crowd than any assembled by a Democrat campaigning in the state.
"There is one thing that's universal, and that is anxiety," said Rufus Gifford, who served as finance director for President Obama's re-election campaign and has contributed to several campaigns. 





Pete Buttigieg spoke at a rally in Nashua, N.H., on Sunday. PHOTO: Gabriela Bhaskar for The Wall Street Journal
The fear among some Democrats is predicated on the idea that Mr. Sanders, the Vermont senator and self-described democratic socialist, would struggle to defeat Mr. Trump in November. Mr. Sanders and his supporters believe the party could unite around him if he is the nominee and that he could energize young voters and those in crucial Rust Belt states who swung to the GOP in 2016.
The Sanders campaign disputed the notion he would hurt Democrats in swing districts, noting that candidates in states that will be crucial in 2020 had requested his help during 2018 midterms.
Mr. Sanders and Mr. Buttigieg, a 38-year-old newcomer to the national scene, essentially tied in Iowa and finished one-two in New Hampshire. Ms. Warren has faded in the first two contests but is pressing forward, while Ms. Klobuchar, the No. 3 finisher in New Hampshire, is eyeing delegates when her home state of Minnesota votes on March 3.
If Mr. Biden has a strong showing in South Carolina and Nevada, he could regain lost momentum and potentially persuade wavering Democrats to stick with him through subsequent states.
Mr. Bloomberg meanwhile has poured more than $350 million of his fortune into a series of March states, including California, Texas and North Carolina.
Philip Levine, a former mayor of Miami Beach, Fla., who supports Mr. Bloomberg, said in an interview he received "an avalanche" of phone calls and emails Wednesday from donors asking how they could help, and from elected officials, whom he didn't name, asking his advice on "how to tactfully retract" their endorsements of Mr. Biden and shift their support to Mr. Bloomberg.
Some Democratic donors say privately there will be a lot of pressure for Mr. Biden to get out after South Carolina if he performs poorly there.
"We are going to compete in Super Tuesday states," said Rep. Cedric Richmond of Louisiana, a Biden campaign co-chairman. "Bloomberg is spending an awful lot of money, but he's also not had his turn in the barrel. He has not been on the debate stage. He's untested."
Larry Rasky, who leads a pro-Biden super PAC called Unite the Country, sought to rally Biden donors in a fundraising memo Sunday by telling them that if they hedge their bets on Mr. Biden because of Mr. Bloomberg, they could be creating a "doomsday scenario."
"The Sanders-Warren wing of the Party is ready for the Bloomberg fight. Democrats cannot afford a split Convention. Do you really think the Sanders voters wing will support Mike Bloomberg? Do you think all the camps who have busted their butts and played by the rules will happily sign on" to Mr. Bloomberg's campaign, he wrote.
The party's attempt to present itself as a steady, competent alternative to Mr. Trump has been
marred by the chaotic Iowa caucuses
, where more than a week later Mr. Sanders narrowly trails Mr. Buttigieg in state delegates, but Mr. Sanders leads in the popular vote. Both candidates have requested a recanvassing of certain precincts.
Party strategists are watching early-state turnout closely for clues about whether Democrats are energized to vote. 





Sen. Bernie Sanders drew crowds at a rally at the University of New Hampshire on Monday. PHOTO: Gabriela Bhaskar for The Wall Street Journal
More than 176,000 people participated in the Iowa Democratic caucuses this year, a slight increase from four years ago but well behind the nearly 240,000 who caucused in 2008. New Hampshire was a brighter spot for Democrats: Turnout reached about 297,000 voters in the Democratic primary, compared with about 255,000 in 2016 and nearly 290,000 in 2008.
"Everything is splintered," said Chris Kofinis, a Democratic strategist and former adviser to West Virginia Sen. Joe Manchin. "And it just shows that voters aren't falling in love with any of these candidates, and that's a problem."
Celinda Lake, a Democratic pollster who has conducted focus groups in early-voting states and general-election battlegrounds, said she has been struck by "the duality of who you like and who you think can beat Trump. And they're not necessarily the same thing." 





Joe Biden, seen speaking in Iowa earlier this month, has faltered in the first two primary contests. PHOTO: Christopher Lee for The Wall Street Journal
In a sign of Democrats' interest in finding an alternative to Mr. Biden, some moderate House Democrats have embraced Mr. Bloomberg, including Reps. Mikie Sherrill of New Jersey, Haley Stevens of Michigan and Scott Peters of California. On Wednesday, two African-American members of Congress, Reps. Lucy McBath (D., Ga.) and Gregory Meeks (D., N.Y.) said they were backing Mr. Bloomberg. All are members of the centrist New Democrat Coalition.
Rep. Stephanie Murphy, the chairwoman of the centrist Blue Dog Coalition caucus, said Mr. Sanders wouldn't be able to win over swing voters, and if he becomes the party's nominee, he could put the new House majority at risk. "For many moderate districts and Trump-won districts, Bernie Sanders at the top of the ticket would create headwinds for house members running for re-election," she said.
Related
*
Candidates Set for Long Haul Following Sanders's New Hampshire Win

*
New Hampshire Primary: Top Takeaways

*
Buttigieg Faces Tough Path in Next Democratic Contests

*
How Iowa and New Hampshire Have Reshaped Democratic Race

*
Iowa Democratic Party Chairman to Resign Position After Caucus Debacle

Former Goldman Sachs Chief Executive Lloyd Blankfein, who supported Hillary Clinton in 2016, said in a tweet Tuesday that "Sanders is just as polarizing as Trump AND he'll ruin our economy." Mr. Sanders's campaign manager tweeted back: "This is what panic from the Wall Street elite looks and sounds like."
For most of the campaign, Mr. Biden has presented himself as the candidate best able to win states narrowly carried by Mr. Trump, including his boyhood state of Pennsylvania, Michigan and Wisconsin.
"He did not have a shot to win Iowa or do well in Iowa," said Rep. Tim Ryan (D., Ohio), who endorsed Mr. Biden after his own candidacy failed. "His two strongest groups are communities of color and older voters, and both are pretty much excluded from the caucus process."
Mr. Biden and his wife, Dr. Jill Biden, joined a conference call with the campaign's top financial donors on Wednesday afternoon, according to three participants, and noted the campaign's strength in Nevada and South Carolina among Latinos and African-Americans.
Polls indicate that Mr. Buttigieg and Ms. Klobuchar both have struggled to appeal to African-American voters. Mr. Bloomberg apologized for a second time Tuesday amid a fresh round of criticism for his support of stop-and-frisk policing in New York City.
Mr. Sanders has argued that Democrats must nominate someone who can generate enthusiasm and mobilize young people and infrequent voters who were turned off by their choices in the 2016 election. The senator has arguably the best ability to command large crowds, evidenced by more than 7,500 people who showed up for a primary eve rally and concert at the University of New Hampshire.
In the last week, Mr. Sanders has taken the lead in the RealClearPolitics average of national Democratic primary polls, after Mr. Biden had led for months.
While Mr. Biden's candidacy has foundered, Mr. Bloomberg has courted members of Congress. In January, Mr. Bloomberg flew to Salt Lake City where Rep. Ben McAdams (D., Utah) hosted the former mayor at his home with local Democrats and Republicans. Mr. Bloomberg talked about his hope for a pragmatic government and answered questions on climate change and fiscal responsibility.
Mr. McAdams said he was looking for someone he could support, but also said he was looking for someone who understood a congressional district like his own, which the president carried by 7 percentage points in 2016.
About a week later, he endorsed Mr. Bloomberg.
Tarini Parti contributed to this article.
Share Your Thoughts
Which moderate in the Democratic primary race do you think could hold their own in a general election against President Trump? Why? Join the conversation below.
Write to Ken Thomas at
ken.thomas@wsj.com
and Natalie Andrews at
Natalie.Andrews@wsj.com

title: Trump Administration to Make 35,000 Additional Seasonal Worker H-2B Visas Available; Of the total visas available, 10,000 will be reserved for people from Guatemala, Honduras and El Salvador
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON—The Trump administration said it is making an additional 35,000 seasonal guest-worker visas available this year ahead of the busy summer season, the largest increase since President Trump took office.
The additional visas announced Thursday by the Department of Homeland Security will bring the total available this year to 101,000, though the additional visas will primarily be made available to returning workers.
The seasonal-worker visa program, known as H-2B, enables U.S. employers to hire as many as 66,000 foreign workers a year, with the allotments split evenly between the winter and summer seasons. Congress permits the Department of Homeland Security each year to raise that cap by as many as 64,000 additional visas. This year's cap is slightly higher than the 30,000 workers the administration allowed last year.
DHS is adding new restrictions on the additional visas, which some administration officials and outside critics of the move said could limit how many of the visas will actually be used.
The visas will become available to employers in two tranches: 20,000 immediately and an additional 15,000 for employees beginning work on or after May 15.
Of the 35,000 total, 10,000 will be set aside for workers from Guatemala, Honduras and El Salvador, the only countries that will be allowed to send new applicants. Those three Central American countries, collectively known as the Northern Triangle, accounted for the majority of asylum seekers crossing the border illegally last year. DHS officials said that providing these people a pathway to work lawfully in the U.S. will reduce the incentive to migrate illegally.
"The department is taking significant steps to promote integrity in the program, combat fraud and abuse, and ensure the supplemental allocation aligns with the national interest," a DHS spokeswoman said.
The additional visas are being made available ahead of the summer, when demand for short-term work is typically highest. Still, demand has routinely outstripped the available cap. Landscapers, fisheries, county fairs and holiday resorts—including Mr. Trump's own golf and beach clubs—all use the H-2B program to fill lower-skilled jobs.
The departments of Homeland Security and Labor had for weeks pushed for the cap to be raised by 45,000 additional visas this year, more in line with industry demands.
That higher number of visas had been approved by the White House. But the administration began facing backlash from groups advocating more immigration restrictions after
The Wall Street Journal reported
on the administration's plan. Stephen Miller, President Trump's top immigration adviser, argued internally that proceeding with the higher number risked displeasing the president's base, which views immigration skeptically, as the election season ramps up, people familiar with the discussions said.
The White House didn't respond to a request for comment.
"It's less than the lobbyists [seeking additional guest-worker visas] were pushing for, but there's still no excuse for the administration raising it at all," said Mark Krikorian, executive director of the Center for Immigration Studies, a group arguing for lower levels of immigration. "There's no limit to the number of cheap foreign workers that employers in landscaping and hotels and restaurants could hire. This is preferable because it's easier and cheaper."
Thursday's decision comes amid a
broader debate
inside the Trump administration over legal immigration, with some officials arguing American workers will see wages rise only if foreign workers are prevented from competing with them for jobs and undercutting them, while others believe more immigrants are needed to sustain the economic growth that Mr. Trump will put at the center of his re-election campaign.
Guest workers, like few other issues in immigration, muddle partisan lines, where Republicans who support pro-business initiatives and Democrats who advocate for immigrant rights find themselves at odds with labor unions and immigration hard-liners.
At a Senate hearing last week, Sens. Jeanne Shaheen, a New Hampshire Democrat, and James Lankford, an Oklahoma Republican, pushed acting Homeland Security Secretary Chad Wolf to raise the H-2B visa cap by the maximum allowed under the law.
"Without immediate and meaningful H-2B cap relief, seasonal businesses will be forced to scale back operations, cancel or default on contracts, lay off full-time U.S. workers and, in some cases, close operations completely," a bipartisan group of 189 lawmakers wrote in a
January letter
to Mr. Wolf.
Judith Ogden, who owns a landscaping business on Long Island, said she redoubled her efforts to find American workers during her busy summer season in 2017, when Congress scaled back the annual allowance of guest workers, taking out advertisements and offering slightly more pay. But she said she couldn't find many takers, and the smaller workforce hurt her business.
"In reality Americans suffer," she said. "When I can't get my workers, I have to lay off Americans that I employ and I can't purchase from local vendors."
Top White House officials including Mr. Miller have successfully pushed through numerous policy changes that would shrink most forms of legal immigration. The most significant of those policies, the public-charge rule, which will essentially impose an income test on future green-card applicants, took effect last week.
Jared Kushner, the president's adviser and son-in-law, has been encouraged by success with the bipartisan criminal-justice overhaul passed last year and has been circulating a draft of an immigration plan to Republican lawmakers. He has also pushed the idea of coupling the bill, which focuses on border security, with a bill providing a path to legalization for the so-called Dreamers, young immigrants who came to the U.S. illegally as children.
On Thursday, Mr. Trump and Mr. Kushner led a meeting at the White House with several Republican senators, including Lindsey Graham of South Carolina, Tom Cotton of Arkansas and David Perdue of Georgia, to discuss the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, which is under review by the Supreme Court.
Republican Senate aides said that senators and members of the administration remain torn over whether they should restart DACA negotiations ahead of a potential high court decision striking down the program, with Mr. Graham arguing in favor of a fix ahead of November's election and Mr. Cotton arguing forcefully against touching the issue.
Write to Michelle Hackman at
Michelle.Hackman@wsj.com

title: Trump's Loyal Base in Ohio Supports His Iran Strategy; President's re-election campaign seizes moment to portray him as a strong commander
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
COLUMBUS, Ohio—As President Trump
backs away from conflict with Iran
, some of his most loyal supporters say they never worried about the clash getting out of hand.
In the battleground state of Ohio, Trump backers attending a Wednesday campaign event with the president's daughter-in-law, Lara Trump, said they supported Mr. Trump's move to
take out an Iranian military leader
and that they didn't believe he was ever going to send ground troops into the country, based on his opposition to what he calls "endless wars."
"I come from a solid military family, so I know what it is to lose somebody," said Sherry Laughman, 57 years old, of Galena. "He has from the beginning said he was not in it to start a war."
Martha Verblaauw, also 57 and from Worthington, echoed that sentiment, saying: "I knew it wasn't going to happen. He literally follows through on things he's said from way back when."
SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS
How do you think President Trump's decision to strike against Iran will affect the presidential race? Join the conversation below.
As Mr. Trump heads to Ohio on Thursday for his first major campaign rally since his confrontation with Iran intensified, his campaign is seizing the moment to portray him as a strong commander, touting the killing of an Iranian military leader and targeting what they see as mixed messages from Democrats. But the approach comes with risks, among them that should the conflict escalate, the president may turn off antiwar supporters.
The threat of conflict with Iran intensified last week with the U.S. strike against
Maj. Gen. Qassem Soleimani
. The president sought to take down the temperature Wednesday, signaling no more military strikes after an
Iranian missile barrage on U.S. bases
, which was seen as a tempered response to the killing.
The president's re-election campaign has kept up its tough rhetoric.
Soon after the U.S. took out Gen. Soleimani, the Trump campaign sent out an email titled "ANOTHER dead terrorist," building on their tough talk after the
raid that killed an ISIS leader last year
. After the president's relatively measured address Wednesday, the campaign blasted a text to supporters, directing them to a survey that asked if they would prefer Mr. Trump in office or a "terrorist-apologist Democrat."
For their part, Democrats are casting Mr. Trump's effort as another example of a reckless policy. Speaking at a fundraiser Tuesday, former Vice President Joe Biden said: "We are alone now—we're alone and we will have to bear the cost of Donald Trump's folly."
Antiwar activists and lawmakers hosted a call Wednesday night with two Democratic presidential candidates where they discussed demonstrations set for Thursday in opposition to military action in the Middle East. Sens. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and Bernie Sanders of Vermont spoke briefly and urged listeners to be active in their resistance.
"This is the moment that Americans need to speak up and say we do not want another war in the Middle East, we do not want war with Iran," Ms. Warren said.
Mr. Trump's campaign has sought to highlight inconsistencies in Mr. Biden's foreign policy record, as well as slam Mr. Sanders and Ms. Warren for their rhetoric about the strike against Gen. Soleimani.
"Now they are trying to defend killing a terrorist," Ms. Trump said Wednesday in Columbus. "What is going on with the Democrats?"
From the Oval Office Tuesday, Mr. Trump said: "I don't hear too many people other than politicians who are trying to win the presidency, those are the ones that are complaining, but I don't hear anybody else complaining."
Some Democratic voters in Ohio expressed frustration over Mr. Trump's tactics with Iran, although these voters said they had largely already made up their minds not to support him in 2020.
"It puts his foreign policy ineptitude on display," said Andy Steele, 46, of Columbus, who works for a technology company and plans to vote Democratic. Tom Hohenberger, a 64-year-old retired nurse from Columbus who also plans to vote Democratic, said, "I think he didn't get the right kind of briefing."
Rose Mary Blair, a 57-year-old project manager who attended an event in Akron for 2020 hopeful Michael Bloomberg Wednesday, said she thinks Mr. Trump's recent moves against Iran "put a lot of young people and our country at risk."
Mr. Trump's entanglement with Iran offers the latest example of a foreign policy that has long swung between aggressive and isolationist impulses. As a candidate, he pledged to stop "endless wars," but also promised to build up the U.S. military. In office he has sought to withdraw troops from the Middle East while also promising to unleash "fire and fury" in the face of a nuclear threat.
Those close to the president said his views have always been complicated. Said one Trump ally: "Trump was never, never a noninterventionist in the way that Ron Paul was a noninterventionist."
Some Trump backers said they would be comfortable even if he did send troops into Iran, saying they trusted his judgment.
"If they want, I'll come out of retirement and I'll go over there" and help, said Curtis Stroede, 66, of Chillicothe, who is a veteran. "He's showing strength, he's pushing back on bullies, he's showing them he's willing and able."
Tarini Parti and Eliza Collins contributed to this article.
Write to Catherine Lucey at
catherine.lucey@wsj.com

title: What Has Happened Since House Vote to Impeach; As lawmakers wrangle over which documents and witnesses should appear in the Senate trial, here's what's new
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON—Nearly a month passed between the House vote to impeach President Trump and its
transmission of the articles of impeachment
to the Senate.
In that time, Democrats say,
new information has raised the need for additional documents
to be subpoenaed and witnesses called, which senators will vote on after the trial begins. Mr. Trump's legal team argues
the articles of impeachment are frivolous and dangerous
and should be swiftly rejected by the Senate.
Here's what has happened since the House vote:
Giuliani associate makes a splash
Lev Parnas, who assisted Trump lawyer Rudy Giuliani in his push for the Ukrainian investigations, in recent weeks
turned over documents to the House Intelligence Committee
that reveal new details about the extent of their efforts.
In prime-time interviews last week, Mr. Parnas, who has been
indicted on campaign-finance charges
in a separate matter, said Mr. Trump knew what he was doing and "was aware of all of my movements."
The text messages Mr. Parnas provided to the House don't corroborate his assertion that the president was aware of his activities, but do outline the
close relationship he established with Mr. Giuliani
and other high-level associates of Mr. Trump.
Documents released by the House on Tuesday included a letter in which Mr. Giuliani said he was seeking a meeting with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky
with Mr. Trump's "knowledge and consent."
Mr. Zelensky didn't end up taking the meeting, fearful of getting sucked into a U.S. political drama.
Congress's watchdog finds hold on Ukraine funds broke the law
Congress's nonpartisan watchdog agency, the Government Accountability Office, released a report finding that the Trump administration
lacked the legal authority to put the Ukraine security assistance on hold.

Related
*
White House Calls Charges 'Frivolous' and 'Dangerous'

*
Democrats Outline Case for Removing Trump

*
Trump's GOP Support Remains Solid Through Impeachment

*
Lev Parnas Paid His Way Into Trump's Orbit

GAO wrote that the White House Office of Management and Budget improperly froze the money for policy reasons, in violation of federal law requiring the president to spend funds appropriated by Congress except under limited circumstances.
A spokeswoman for OMB said the office disagreed with GAO's opinion and said it had authority "to ensure taxpayer dollars are properly spent consistent with the President's priorities and with the law."
Connecticut Republican's texts suggest he had ambassador under surveillance
Among the disclosures in the trove of documents released by Mr. Parnas through the House: Information that prompted Ukraine's Interior Ministry to
launch its own probe
of "whether there were any violations of Ukrainian and international laws…or [if it was] just bravado and fake talk in an informal conversation between two U.S. citizens."
In the documents, a long-shot Connecticut Republican House candidate who runs a landscaping business suggested in text messages to Mr. Parnas that he had then-U.S. Ambassador to Ukraine Marie Yovanovitch under surveillance. The candidate, Robert Hyde, has said his texts to Mr. Parnas were a joke and that he didn't monitor the ambassador's movements. Mr. Parnas has said he didn't believe Mr. Hyde was surveilling Ms. Yovanovitch.
Still, Federal Bureau of Investigation personnel visited Mr. Hyde's Connecticut home and business last week, according to a person familiar with the matter.
OMB directed officials to 'hold off' releasing Ukraine funds after Trump-Zelensky call
In December, the Defense Department released a batch of emails, including one sent July 25 by a senior official at the White House Office of Management and Budget asking Pentagon officials to hold off releasing funds for Ukraine pending the administration's review.
The official, OMB Associate Director for National-Security Programs Michael Duffey, sent the email less than two hours after Mr. Trump pressed his Ukrainian counterpart to undertake the investigations into Mr. Biden and alleged election interference—two investigations that could benefit him politically.
Mr. Trump had ordered nearly $400 million in aid to Ukraine frozen weeks before the phone call, The Wall Street Journal has reported. The assistance was ultimately released.
'I am speechless'
New emails showed a senior Pentagon official
clashing with the White House
last summer over the decision to freeze security aid to Ukraine. The official warned that the hold could complicate the administration's ability to distribute the money before the congressionally mandated deadline.
In emails to officials at the White House Office of Management and Budget, Elaine McCusker, the acting Pentagon comptroller, raised concerns about the legality of the hold.
Her frustrations escalated in early September. After she warned OMB that the U.S. might not be able to spend $120 million by the end of the fiscal year because of the hold, Mr. Duffey responded with a letter blaming the Defense Department for not doing enough to prepare to spend the funds if they were released.
"You can't be serious," Ms. McCusker replied. "I am speechless."
Bolton willing to testify—if subpoenaed
On Jan. 6, former national-security adviser John Bolton said he
would testify in a Senate trial if subpoenaed
by lawmakers—which remains unlikely.
Current and former National Security Council officials have testified that Mr. Bolton was alarmed by the push for investigations in Ukraine and urged aides to report their concerns to a White House lawyer.
Mr. Bolton's lawyer has suggested his client's testimony would be tantalizing.
In a letter to the House lawyer in November
, he said Mr. Bolton knew about "many relevant meetings and conversations" that had not yet been made public.
SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS
Is there a case for impeachment for President Trump? Why or why not? Join the conversation below.
Write to Rebecca Ballhaus at
Rebecca.Ballhaus@wsj.com

title: Democrats Present Case that Trump Impeded Congressional Investigation; Friday marks the last chance for impeachment managers to make pitch to GOP senators
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
WASHINGTON—House Democrats fought to win over enough Republican senators to subpoena witnesses and documents in President Trump's impeachment trial, seeking to drive home charges of abuse of office and obstruction of Congress in their third and final day of opening arguments.
Mr. Trump "invited foreign interference in our elections and sold out our country's security for his personal benefit, and betrayed the nation's trust to a foreign power," said House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff (D., Calif.).
Friday marked the last chance for the Democratic impeachment managers—House lawmakers acting as prosecutors—to make their pitch to GOP senators who may be wavering on whether to subpoena witnesses and documents that were withheld from House impeachment investigators by the White House.
It would take a simple majority of 51 senators to vote for the additional evidence, meaning that at least four Republicans would have to join all 47 senators in the Democratic caucus to pass such a motion. If Democrats can't muster those four GOP votes, the trial could end as soon as next week.
Republican Sens. Susan Collins of Maine, Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, Mitt Romney of Utah and Lamar Alexander of Tennessee are among those who have said they would be open to witnesses. They have been tight-lipped in recent days about how the Democrats' opening arguments might have affected their thinking.
Mr. Romney reiterated Friday that he would like to hear testimony from former national security adviser John Bolton, and he said he would make a decision about other officials later in the trial. Mr. Bolton, who was described by witnesses as alarmed at the pressure put on Ukraine,
said earlier this month that he would testify
in a Senate trial if subpoenaed by lawmakers.
Mr. Alexander told reporters Friday that he will make his decision after the questioning portion of the trial, expected next week. "I think that question can only be answered then," he said.
SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS
Do you think Democrats will be able to sway enough Republican senators to break ranks and agree to subpoena witnesses and documents? Why or why not? Join the conversation below.
The House impeached Mr. Trump last month over allegations that the president
withheld nearly $400 million in military aid
to Ukraine as part of an effort to pressure Kyiv to open investigations into Vice President Joe Biden, a Democratic political rival, and then obstructed House investigators probing the matter.
Mr. Trump says he did nothing wrong and has called the impeachment a hoax driven by politics. He derided the Democrats' presentation in a tweet Friday, saying "the Do Nothing Democrats just keep repeating and repeating, over and over again, the same old 'stuff' on the Impeachment Hoax."
White House officials have said they don't expect any Republicans to vote in favor of hearing from more witnesses, but Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R., Ky.) is privately far less certain, people familiar with the talks said.
The White House has largely delegated the task of rallying senators to vote against witness testimony to Mr. McConnell and a handful of other senators, though some White House officials including the president have been in contact with lawmakers as the trial has unfolded.
During the trial, Mr. McConnell is using daily closed-door lunches as a venue for GOP senators to have frank exchanges and relay feedback to party leadership.
Among the arguments some Republicans are making at lunch and in private conversations is that voting in favor of witness testimony would further prolong the trial with an extended court battle over executive privilege, people familiar with the talks said. Republicans also contend that witness testimony won't change the case and that the trial should end by the Feb. 4 State of the Union address.
Mr. McConnell has made that case publicly, saying in remarks on the Senate floor on Tuesday that pursuing new witnesses could indefinitely delay the Senate trial and draw the body into a protracted and complex legal fight. "Such litigation could potentially have permanent repercussions for the separation of powers and the institution of the presidency that senators would need to consider very carefully," he said.
Mr. Schiff told reporters on Friday that it is "nonsense" that subpoenaing new witnesses or documents could make the trial last too long. "This is not a trial over a speeding ticket or shopping ticket, this is an impeachment trial involving the president of the United States," Mr. Schiff told reporters on Friday. "These witnesses have important first-hand testimony to offer, the House wishes to call them in the name of the American people and the American people overwhelmingly want to hear what they have to say."
Sixty-six percent of Americans say the Senate should call witnesses to testify in Mr. Trump's impeachment trial, including 45% of Republicans, 65% of independents and 87% of Democrats, according to an
ABC News/Washington Post poll
released on Friday.
Rep. Jason Crow (D., Colo.) led off the Democratic arguments Friday, wrapping up managers' presentation of the
first article of impeachment
. That charge alleges Mr. Trump abused his power by withholding Ukraine aid as leverage for the country to open investigations into Mr. Biden.
Mr. Crow ran through the chronology surrounding the aid freeze, which was later released amid media reports and a bipartisan outcry in Congress. The hold on the aid "wasn't lifted for any legitimate reason," Mr. Crow said. "It was only lifted because President Trump had gotten caught."
Managers were spending the bulk of Friday, however, on the second article of impeachment, which accuses Mr. Trump of trying to thwart
the House inquiry
by directing witnesses not to testify and refusing to allow the release of documents, and ordering executive branch agencies to do the same.
House committees issued document requests or subpoenas last year to the White House, the Office of the Vice President, Office of Management and Budget, the State Department, Department of Defense, and the Energy Department.
Democrats have stressed that the Trump administration refused to produce any documents in response to those subpoenas, even though witness testimony during the House inquiry revealed that relevant records exist.
They also were likely to highlight the White House's decision to block witnesses who have firsthand knowledge of Mr. Trump's decision to withhold assistance to Ukraine, including acting White House chief of staff Mick Mulvaney and Mr. Bolton.
Related Stories
*
Democrats Focus on Abuse of Power

*
Trial Ramps Up Political Spending

*
Amid Trump Trial, Pompeo Plans Trip to Ukraine

*
Analysis: Trump Impeachment Trial

Trump attorney Jay Sekulow rejected Democrats' push for more documents on Thursday, saying the president was within his rights to withhold them.
"The Constitution protects executive privilege, there's a reason for that," he said, citing the principle presidents use to protect communications with close aides and advisers from public scrutiny. The argument is that confidentiality is needed to protect national security and to enable the president to receive frank advice.
Executive privilege isn't explicitly mentioned in the Constitution but is understood to be implied by its separation of powers.
Democrats say executive privilege shouldn't be used to shield a president engaged in alleged misconduct.
In 1974, the Supreme Court ruled in United States v. Nixon that executive privilege couldn't be used to keep information from a prosecutor investigating a crime, but the case didn't settle the question as it relates to Congress during an impeachment inquiry or trial.
The Nixon-era Justice Department suggested at the time that a presidential refusal to comply with a congressional subpoena during an impeachment trial could spark "a constitutional confrontation of the highest magnitude."
Mr. Trump maintains he did nothing wrong and has called the impeachment a hoax driven by politics. He derided the Democrats' presentation in a tweet Friday, saying "the Do Nothing Democrats just keep repeating and repeating, over and over again, the same old 'stuff' on the Impeachment Hoax."
As vice president, Mr. Biden helped lead an international anticorruption push in Ukraine at a time when Hunter Biden served on the board of a Ukranian natural-gas company. Mr. Trump and his allies have accused the elder Mr. Biden of working to replace a Ukrainian prosecutor to protect his son, but Mr. Biden pressed for the removal with the backing of U.S. allies at a time when the prosecutor's probe into Burisma, the gas company, was dormant.
Capital Journal In Your Inbox
Get the latest scoops, analysis and insights driving Washington from the WSJ's D.C. bureau, with Capital Journal.
Sign up.

The Bidens have strenuously denied any wrongdoing.
Rebecca Ballhaus contributed to this article.
Write to Lindsay Wise at
lindsay.wise@wsj.com

title: Republican Bill Weld Makes Little Traction in New York in Run Against Trump; Top GOP official in the state doubts the former Massachusetts governor will make the April 28 primary ballot
text:
Hide highlightingFull TextTranslateUndo Translation FromToTranslateTranslation in progress... 

[[missing key: loadingAnimation]]The full text may take 40-120 seconds to translate; larger documents may take longer.

Cancel
OverlayEndTurn on search term navigationTurn on search term navigation
| Jump to first hit
Former Massachusetts Gov. William Weld says his Republican primary
challenge to President Trump
is a moral question for the party, but the top GOP official in New York doubts he'll even make the April 28 primary ballot.
Mr. Weld, who ran the Bay State from 1991 to 1997, was born on Long Island and owns homes in both the Catskills and Adirondacks. He ran for New York governor in 2006 but ultimately lost the GOP nomination to John Faso. Democrat Eliot Spitzer won the general election.
Mr. Weld ran for vice president on the Libertarian Party ticket in 2016 and said he is challenging President Trump for the GOP nomination this year because of his moral character, his environmental positions and his fiscal policies.
"There is a Republican alternative to Trump," Mr. Weld said. "My view is that it's Mr. Trump who's the Republican in name only, and he's forsaken bedrock Republican principles like economic conservatism, conserving the environment and fully engaging with the world."
A Trump campaign spokesman declined to comment.
Mr. Weld's establishment pedigree—Harvard, Oxford, Ronald Reagan's Justice Department—should appeal naturally to whatever number of Republicans remain skeptical of Mr. Trump. But despite his New York roots, Mr. Weld hasn't drawn support from any prominent Republicans in the state who resisted Trump in 2016 and is being shunned by its formal party apparatus.
"I would be very surprised if he had any traction whatsoever," NYGOP Chairman Nick Langworthy said of Mr. Weld, pointing to the strength of the economy. "I think his candidacy is kind of a joke, and it's a bunch of sour-grapes Republicans who still can't get their head around the fact that their candidate of choice lost in 2016."
The Weld campaign has failed to make the ballot in Kentucky, Oklahoma and Ohio. Other states have canceled their GOP primaries. To qualify in New York, Mr. Weld can circulate petitions, meet a national donor threshold or be certified as "nationally known and recognized" by the Republican commissioners of the State Board of Elections.
Candidates must then file a slate of 162 potential delegates, and alternates, to the Republican National Committee's August nominating convention. Mr. Langworthy said he doubted Mr. Weld could accomplish that task by the Feb. 25 deadline.
A Weld campaign spokesman said it hadn't determined exactly how it would apply for a spot on the New York ballot, and declined to release the names of any potential delegates. During a recent interview, Mr. Weld asked a reporter about the exact date of the New York primary.
A Siena College Research Institute poll released last week found 70% of New York Republicans surveyed have a favorable opinion of the president. The poll didn't ask about Mr. Weld.
The Weld campaign raised $1.3 million as of September, including just over $100,000 from New York donors, according to the nonpartisan Center for Responsive Politics. That's more than donations from any other state except Massachusetts, but New York's Trump skeptics are hardly rallying behind Mr. Weld.
U.S. Rep. John Katko, who said he didn't vote for Mr. Trump in 2016, told the Syracuse Post-Standard editorial board that he would support the president this year. So will Chris Jacobs, a state senator from the Buffalo suburbs who was Mr. Weld's running mate in 2006. Mr. Jacobs is running for Congress.
Former U.S. Rep. Richard Hanna, a Republican from Utica who endorsed Hillary Clinton in the last election and describes himself as a Never Trumper, said he didn't know enough about Mr. Weld's campaign to say if he would support it. Dutchess County Executive Marc Molinaro, the GOP's 2018 gubernatorial nominee, didn't reply to inquiries asking if he would support Mr. Weld after writing in the name of another Republican in 2016.
"There really is no Weld campaign in New York, so actively supporting him would be nothing more than a statement," said William F.B. O'Reilly, a Republican political consultant who said he would happily vote against Mr. Trump but was turned off by Mr. Weld's support of abortion rights.
THE MEDICAID TEAM: New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo is banking on an outside panel, dubbed the Medicaid Redesign Team, to find $2.5 billion in savings in the health-care program to help him bridge a $6.1 billion deficit. But that is about all we know.
State Sen. Gustavo Rivera, a Bronx Democrat who chairs the chamber's health committee, said he was concerned about the lack of details and who would be able to participate in the process.
"This is a black box," he said.
As he unveiled his $178 billion spending plan last week, Mr. Cuomo said the panel would be co-chaired by Northwell Health President Michael Dowling and Dennis Rivera, the former leader of Local 1199 of the Service Employees International Union, which represents health-care workers.
A spokesman for Mr. Cuomo said the administration would "soon finalize membership for the Medicaid Redesign Team, as well as the scope and process, and those details will be publicly released."
THE QUESTION: Mr. Cuomo departed for Poland Sunday to attend a Holocaust remembrance service. The nation also shares its moniker with a village in upstate New York, where lots of municipalities are named after Old World locales. How many pairs of countries and their capital cities can you find among New York's municipalities? (For example, Warsaw, in Wyoming County, makes a pair with Poland.)
—Know the answer? Leave a comment!
THE LAST ANSWER: Before Mr. Cuomo took office in 2011, governors had traditionally delivered their annual State of the State addresses in the Assembly chamber on the third floor of the State Capitol.
Write to Jimmy Vielkind at
Jimmy.Vielkind@wsj.com
